The four main characters depicted in the film come from different backgrounds and hold different understandings of love, yet I think they share one thing in common, which is that they are strangers to others. They might be close as lovers or wife and husband, yet they hardly know their partners and even themselves. Truth and lies intervene. Does love offer enough courage to face betrayals and enough support to defeat them? Probably not.

Larry loves in an almost crucially honest way. He confesses his adultery in New York and demands to know every dirty detail from his wife of her adultery with Dan. He seeks joy of revenge by crashing down Dan's dream of pure love with both Anna and Alice. On the other hand, Dan constantly falls in love at the first sight. He leaves Alice for Anna, he walks away on Anna then for her "final" sex with Larry, and he comes to Alice after all the buzz. He did all them because he thinks he was pursuing love. For me, he is the one who is truly pathetic. While he is busy chasing his dream as writer and his dream of perfect pure love, he can only be disappointed again and again. When he looks at the mirror in the hotel and steps outside the elevator to tell Alice he loves her despite her relationship with Larry, it is the moment of love. Ironically, it comes after his talk with Larry, and he comes to Larry, in the first place, to highlight his love for Anna and blame Larry for sabotage their romantic relationship.

Which one is closer, your loving partner whom you think you know or a stranger that you immediately fall in love at the first sight? I do not know. Perhaps you should watch it and tell me about it. However, you may find it not worthy of time.

title: closer
review: The movie excels at describing vividly about people's attitude towards sex and love, which are probably the most controversial topics in our daily life. Actually, I am not surprised at all about its way of presenting the crashes between love and sex. Mike Nichols sees through people's deepest minds and explodes the so-called dark-sides to us all. For example, Alice's (Natalie Portman) vulnerability in front of love, Anna's (Julia Roberts) hesitation in choosing between love and sex, Dan's (Jude Law) naiveness and 'inexperience' in dealing with what he thinks as the 'true love', Larry's (Clive Owen) complicity and his complicated handling of conflicts between love and sex. These four characters represent different attitudes on how we judge and make decisions in the matter of love and sex. Some people may complain about the explosive depiction of sex, even the abrasive and brutal dialogs on the issue of love, but without doubt, the movie digs out what we are afraid of admitting. We are too shy and self-inclusive towards love and sex, but we hold more expectations of being understood and accepted. So this is the charm of this film---expose the dark sides of love and sex, but to make people more yearning for them.

title: complicated love and life
review: This movie was in many ways not my type, as I prefer those romantic comedies. However, I found it to be a quite authentic and realistic view of what relationships can be. Forgiveness, compromise, mistakes and vulnerability were mingled in the four-angle relationship. perhaps to be hurt by the one you love. In the film are several moments that are so perfectly true and honest that they're painful to watch. Sometimes you are likely to be hurt by the one you love. It seemed like that everyone wanted to know the truth, which yet hurts most. When faced with the truth, people behaved in a totally different way as they promised before. In the end the film became a fight between the two men, showing off their masculine power and natural possessiveness. The direct and faithful way to describe sex and love seemed a little bit over to me, destroying my dream of love. It seemed that falling in love was quite an easy and random thing. The capriciousness of the characters' feelings except for Alice was unbelievable and more than I can understand. She was the only one who had true feelings for Dan while others seemed able to jump into bed with everyone else in a whim. This film cast great irony and sarcasm on modern life and society. A strong contrast was created between the two male characters, seemingly rude and strong Larry never hit Anna whereas gentle Dan slapped Alice at the end of the movie. People lost themselves under tremendous pressure in the materialistic society full of various temptations, with alienation form others and their mental demand failing to fulfill. This film exposed the deepest side of human beings behind their splendid appearances. Those who sell themselves and their souls are not necessarily the strippers, but might be a respectable artist or photographer who appears composed and presentable. And the title of this film 'Closer' also hinted that closer two strangers become; more problems are to come with. Maybe that's why many people now keep a safe distance with others.

title: Love at first sight
review:
"Love is an accident waiting to happen. Desire is a stranger you think you know. Intimacy is a lie we tell ourselves. Truth is a game you play to win. If you believe in love at first sight, you never stop looking."

(From the trailer of the movie)

Do you believe in love at first sight? It seems that the four main characters in the film do. As a result, Alice and Dan came together; Anna and Larry married; Anna and Dan had an affair. They met; they fell in love; and then came deception, betrayal and abandoning. It's the same old story happening every day in our life. Yet the film manages to capture something delicate, something we have been reluctant to admit. That is, the vulnerable and deceptive nature of love.

Love is an accident waiting to happen. Everything is so beautiful at the very beginning: in the gray damp city of London where 7.5 million people dwell, the eyes of two strangers met in the hustling crowd. "Hello, stranger" is the first word the girl said to the man. Then they fell in love just like the opening of every romantic story.

Desire is a stranger you think you know. Sometimes an intruder can also be quite innocent, just like Anna.This time two strangers again. But the romance came alongside with guilt and deception. Is it desire that connects two wandering souls? Nobody knows exactly.

Intimacy is a lie we tell ourselves. When the initial flush of love evaporates, what is left is a pond of still water, something we call intimacy. But intimacy didn't triumphs over guilty desire. So Dan and Anna have an affair. When the feelings are gone and the heart grows cold, who's to blame? Dan and Anna, or the vulnerability of love itself?

Truth is a game you play to win. Sometimes truth can also be hurtful. When jealousy and suspicion arise, mistrust takes over. Dan loses two most important women in his life. Larry took a successful revenge in the end and won back his wife. But for him, maybe it's only the winning that really matters.

If you believe in love at first sight, you never stop looking. Life continues anyway. Just like what's implied in the end, when Alice, or maybe we should call her Jane, walked down the road, looking straight ahead, we know at that very moment everything is in the past. Life goes on easily most of the time, only in retrospect we pick up those painful memories and smile. The next stranger is around the corner.

title: Love is a lie
review: This is a story between two men and two women, a story about love and betray, gentle lie and hurting truth, stranger and lover. When Alice is saying "I'm waiting for you to leave me.", or " I don't love you anymore since now" I can't help thinking that this is the real situation of "love", so hard to hold, and so easy to come and go. May be I'm a pessimist abut love. In my opinion, love is a lie, and the promise like "I will love you forever" is the biggest one. Biology divides the experience of love into three stages: lust, attraction, and attachment. Lust exposes people to others while romantic attraction encourages human beings to focus their energy on mating. And both of them involve the release of chemicals and both cannot last for long. So only a few can move forward to attachment. The regular form of love is like situations in the film, we easily fall in love with someone because their attractive appearances or after an interesting dialog. Then we keep dating them until we find someone else more attractive. In relationship between two people, if we are the one who loves more, we will be the one "waiting", waiting for the being betrayed, while the other one will be the one "searching", searching for the next lover and start a new circle. Under such circumstance, it is hard to trust as well as to be trusted, so we need lies to cover and it makes us feel safe. During the process that the chemicals released by the brain become less and less, we begin to lie about love until we finally choose to unveil the hurting truth. We are strangers at the very beginning and then lovers, but finally strangers again. Or even, from the begging to the end, we are totally strangers. I still remember at the end of the movie, Alice's real name is indeed Jane Rachel Jones and that she had lied about her name for the duration of her four-year relationship with Dan. So,lovers? Or we all are strangers, all the time.

title: An outstanding movie
review:
Closer is an outstanding movie with complicated love stories. I was at first attracted by the splendid cast rather than the plot. The fetching performances of the four well-known stars starring in it do make what is good still better. In Closer, the four tragic characters play a game called romance and the winner will get true love. But in the end, there is no winner and none of them wins true love. The all lose the game because they thought they can win true love through lies and revenges. In this society, true love is a rarity. So is the movie. It stands out among others of its kind in two aspects. On the one hand, explicit dialogues and vicious statements are frequently presented in Closer. Through the dialogues, we can learn more about the plot, the personalities and emotions of four characters and the secrets below the surface. On the other hand, Closer deals with a distinctive theme – love and sex. It won't be an enjoyment for people who have just begun new relationships or have recently fallen in love. The movie sheds light on the cruel and nasty side of the so-called romance, which is filled with lies, betrayal, revenges and insatiable desires. It may challenge some people's beliefs in true love and provoke them to examine their relationships and souls.

All the four characters have secrets and tell lies in the movie. Dan is in constant pursuit of love at first sight, even though he claims he fancies Alice. The quotation from the movie preview that if you believe in love at first sight, you never stop looking will explain the reason. Alice is a mysterious young woman with sweet and deceptive appearance but a callous heart. She seems to love Dan more than he loves her, but she never reveals her real name to Dan. Anna marries Larry in hope of forgetting Dan, but fails to do so and has secret affairs with him behind Larry's back. Larry coaxes Anna to sleep with him for the last time in exchange for signing the divorce paper, but what he really wants is to get his revenge on Dan for taking Anna away.

I like the scene at Anna's exhibition best. It is the first time and the only time when the four characters show up at the same occasion. Although everyone shakes hands, chats and smiles as he or she is supposed to, I can still feel the tense atmosphere surrounding them. From that moment on, their lives are intertwined in ways they never could have imagined.

It requires much life experience to fully understand the movie. If you just want to get yourself relaxed by watching movies on weekends, Closer won't be a good choice. But it is worth watching and provokes people to ponder over real life.

title: Never Closer
review:
Contrary to the title, "Closer" shows human beings are incapable of getting too close to each other. Beyond a certain point, any attempt to be closer seems futile or even counterproductive.

Like a strip show, the film reveals how unreliable first impressions are, how time takes off people's protecting armor bit by bit and let them prey on each other. The beginning of love is always excitingly beautiful, but as soon as freshness is gone, love is over, its remains fossilizing into hateful fetters. Even before realizing it, people stop getting closer and have more sex only to aggravate the stalemate. It is illusive that two people become one while making love. Judging from the film, their hearts might be a thousand miles apart when their bodies huddle closely. The first crack in Anna and Larry's love appears when Larry spots Anna talk to Dan in her exhibition. Apologizing for sneering at his jealousy, Anna wraps her arms around Larry's shoulders and hugs him tightly, but the hug is devoid of meaning and affection as they are secretly doubting each other's honesty. Many times in the film hugs only bring cold hollowness.

The movie reminds me of love affairs in my surroundings. For over a year a friend of mine loves a man who doesn't love her, gives up, finds a boyfriend adoring her, and falls in love with her boyfriend's friend in a short while. Another friend seems happy with her boyfriend, only to find later that he considers a pretty woman a "goddess", and the lovers turn enemies. As the movie suggests, perhaps love only consists of a short encounter and painful betrayal, which a friend who is deeply in love disagrees, or maybe the film is too real to be true.

In the end all four characters are unhappy. Dan remains a loser; Larry confines Anna to his side, with another round of mutual destruction waiting to happen. Alice, the most innocent compared with the other three, buries her past and begins a new life with a new name in her home country. In the last scene, she strides proudly in a street, smiling as sweetly as in the beginning and attracting nasty men drooling over her. Probably history will repeat itself. After all, human beings are social animals that are incurably tempted by the possibility of getting closer.

title: what is love on earth?
review: When I first saw the movie, I couldn't help thinking "what the hell is this?" But when I saw it again, I found the movie hurts. It seems that it shows the reality of modern relationship, and the truth of love, which really hurts. What is love on earth? People say it all the time, yet they forget to think over what is under the four simple letters. Love itself is simple and sweet, yet when people are involved, it becomes complicated and painful. In the movie, the four characters gain love, get betrayed by love, and then lose love. Their love is full of brutal deception. They are selfish and coward. They say "I love you therefore nothing matters", but actually everything matters. They ask you to trust them, yet they themselves don't trust you and always can't stop testing you. And when love goes away, what to do? Beg her to come back? Turn away and leave with a broken heart? Or end up with a man she doesn't love at all? Maybe the unbelievable and indescribable pain is both the pleasure and the greatest torture of love, and the high price you have to pay when love disappear. Of all the four characters, I love Alice most. She has the face of an angel and the character of a devil. Yet under the pure angelic face and the strong appearance is a fragile heart. Her pure and desperate eyes and the drop of tear on her face tell everyone how love hurts. And when she is betrayed, who can answer her heart-breaking questions? "Why won't you let me love you?" "I amuse you, but I bore you?" "Why isn't love enough?" "Where is this love? I can't see it. I can't touch it. I can't feel it. I can hear it. I can hear some words. But I can't do anything with your easy words." It's true that she lives in a world full of lies yet she loves Dan with a whole heart even when Dan betrayed her. When love is over, she goes back to America with nothing but a broken heart, walking on the street alone, just like five years ago when she was in London. And so it is. What's waiting for her on the next corner, love? Who knows.

title: Hello, Stranger!
review:
The Movie is named as "Closer", meaning the story took place in a weird situation between "Close" and "Closest". "Closer", then raises questions of "binary" -- some relative concepts: "soul" and "lust", "frankness" and "suspicion", "jealousy" and "forgiveness" all of which come down to the deep relation between "closeness" and "strangeness". The focus of the movie is the seemly antagonistic, but in fact indistinguishable binary concepts.

1. Soul and Lust "Sex" and "love", "body" and "soul", "beast" and "human" these three groups of opposing concepts can be best shown through the contrast between Larry and Dan. Larry, the self-proclaimed "Sultan", is most in need of physical and sexual satisfaction. He needs to be absolutely frank, just like naked animals. Anna describes him as rough, direct and high-handed. Larry also considers "sex" the most important element in a marriage. On the other hand, Dan is a cupid. Dan's sensitivity, whole-hearted love, and pursuit of perfection make him sick of Anna and Larry's parting sex. Although he thinks he can forgive Alice and Larry for their sexual relation, but in the end he slapped Alice. We can see that the director does not want to criticize Dan's sorrow and favors Larry's odious behavior, instead, he points out that under no circumstances can "soul" and "lust" separable.

2. Frankness and Deception Compared to their male counterparts, the portrayals of women are more focus on the "love" level. Anna and Alice tell lies, but for the men they loved. Nevertheless, we found that however frank the characters are, it will all return to "suspicion". As in the case Larry urged Alice to tell her real name, even if Alice frankly says her name is Jones, Larry still does not believe her. It can boil down to the fact that, suspicion breeds out of distrust, and distrust result from having been deceived before. Therefore, "honest" is the nickname of "deceit".

3. Jealousy and Forgiveness The relation of "jealousy and forgiveness" is hidden beneath the surface of "sex" and "love". Larry's attitude towards Alice is out of revenge; similarly Larry wants Dan to know that he and Anna have sex before divorce is also a kind of revenge. In the movie, two pairs of men and women whisper with each other is a "demonstration of jealousy." Dan believes that he can forgive Anna which turns out not; Similarly Alice can not forgive Dan, so she no longer cried but indifferently says "I do not love you". In contrast, Anna and Larry's situation appears different, under the surface of the victory does not mean that Larry has no jealousy and forgiveness. Therefore, in the love world, jealousy and forgiveness is not a binary opposition, they coexist.

4. Closeness and Strangeness--fuzzy The movie can be concluded in the guarding theme of "intimate" and "strange", from the stranger's love at first sight at the beginning of the movie to Anna's career of photographing strangers to the seemly closeness between Anna and Larry at the end of the movie. The movie does not completely separate the concept of "close" and "strange". Take Dan and Alice for example, they obviously do not know each other but fall in love at first sight; then they gain better understandings of each other but in the end, Dan finds that Alice has been using a fake name. How to define "close" and "strange"? In the movie, Dan recalls the time when he first met Alice, as if it was the most intimate time between them. So there is no boundary between "closeness" and "strangeness". The movie, I think, is rather vague. The ambiguity of it is also where the attraction lies.

In conclusion, the movie displays the ambiguity of love and life, which is the true nature of them and the true beauty of them.

title: It overturned my view on LOVE
review:
Love is so complicated especially it involves four people. Though I am not sure whether the relationship among them could be called LOVE!

My preconceived idea about LOVE is that it is not just about possession, it is also about tolerance. From this perspective I think Alice is my favorite character. In the photography-room she learns that Dan has feelings for Anna, but she can continue her life with him regardless of that. Compared with Alice, the two male characters are totally selfish and irresponsible. First when Larry knows that Anna had sex with Dan, he was almost freak out and asks every detail about their sex. Oh, this makes me sick! He just wants to stand at a moral height and make Anna feel guilty about her betrayal by recalling those details. Then he meets a stripper who is actually Alice. The fire of revenge in his heart begins to burn. When Dan learns that Anna gets her liberty by having sex with her husband, he could not bear. Maybe Larry knows man like Dan, is just selfish as him, so he knows how things will work out.

The name of the movie is called Closer. What's the deep meaning of the name? Maybe the director tries to tell us that love looks beautiful, but when you get closer, everything collapse. Love is only about biting, brutal and much more about sexual urges.This may pollute our idealistic expectation about love, but this is more Closer to the essence of love. After all, love is not as great as most people think it might be!

title: Nobody Knows What True Love Is
review:
The movie is a direct reflection of the real society in which we are living, a society full of people with spiritual void. They are all seeking for love, or seeking for being loved rather, because they don't know what true love is, neither do the four characters in the movie. Their love is always combined with betrayals, lust, lies, etc.

Dan, the character I dislike most in this movie, has no conception of what love is. To him, love is occupation. He can't accept Anna and Alice's having sex with Larry because he considers them as his own possessions, which can't be shared with someone else. So that means he doesn't allow betrayal in love? No, absolutely no. When he seduces Anna when being taken photos, it disgusts me. How can a man be in love with a woman, and kiss another? He's just a selfish child in the kingdom of love, always wants to get, but never wants to give.

Larry, I think most people view him as a mean guy. His world is filled with lust and sex. To him, Love is sex. At the beginning when he chats online with fake Anna, he wants sex; after he goes to sees Alice at the exhibition, he wants sex; at last before he signs the divorce agreement, he still wants sex. He seems to be always expecting someone to have sex with, rather than someone to love.

Alice, or Jane, it is a big surprise when her real name is shown at last. I don't know why she uses a fake name and why she insists that she can't tell the truth. I tend to like her and have pity on her because she devotes herself to Dan. However, at the ending she disappoints me a lot. Welcome back Miss Jones, and goodbye Alice. She lies to everyone. She loses the fundamental in love, that is, honesty.

Anna, seems to be a rational woman, so rational that she can separate love with sex. Maybe she just wants a quiet life, but things go out of her control. She tries to get Dan out of mind by marrying Larry, tries to have Larry sign the agreement by having sex with him, and tries to have Dan stayed by telling him the truth. Unfortunately, she fails in everything.

At last, nobody gets love, neither the separated nor the couple, because nobody knows what true love is.

title: Men and women are different in love.
review:
It has been such a long time since the first time I watched Closer. Honestly speaking, I had no idea what aspect of love it was about. First sight? Lust? Intimacy? Truth? Or all of them? Maybe the director has too much to convey and just mix it in this movie, which justifies its obscurity. Anyway, after my mind is cleared, what strikes me most is as follows.

Men can fall in love with any woman anytime anywhere, no matter whether he is already with someone or not. They are easily attracted to different kinds of women and wish to taste them all. Men are more selfish in love than women. They think love and sex are separate but they do not allow women to think like that. They can tell calmly, with or without sense of guilt, their once beloved that they do not love them any more, but when deserted or betrayed by women they simply can not act as cool as they desert women.

As to women, they easily fall in love with every man who shows them the least bit of attention. This explains why both Alice and Anna can not resist the passion of Dan, the handsome man who is attracted to both of them. Usually a woman begins to love a man after the man loves her, and once a woman loves a man, she sticks to their love. Here Alice is a perfect example. She is somewhat different from the other three main characters in the movie in that she never leaves the one she loves. Marriage, to a woman, does not necessarily mean living with the man she loves most, but means living with the man who loves her most, which is demonstrated by the case of Anna in the movie. Definitely she loves Dan rather than Larry, but she chooses Larry as her husband eventually.

All in all, I think this movie is thought-provoking and worth watching.

title: perfect strangers
review:
Watching this movie is really torturing. I don't mean the movie itself, but the feeling it brings to me. I see no love and no trust between the characters; I see only desire, revenge, and declaration of occupation--something that will absolutely distort the feeling of love. They name it love, but I don't think so. They think they are lovers, but I don't see that. They are perfect strangers, living in their own worlds, saying loving whisperings to benumb each other, to create a vision that they are in love. The fact is, they love merely themselves. They make use of one or the other of the opposite sex to satisfy their secret, untold and mean lust, seeking salvation in each other's arms. However, sometimes when they become too involved and concentrated, they unconsciously begin to declare their ownership of someone. They kind of believe that someone is meant for them, ignoring the truth that they can never be part of the world of a stranger. The results inevitably turn out to be a tragedy, with fights and distrusts, and broken hearts. But none of them cares about that. They only care about how to be the winner in the war of love, especially the two male characters.

I have been shown a pictorial illustration of human nature. The truest person of the four is no doubt Alice, as she is less hypocritical than the other three. At last she discovered that she loved no one, which has always been the truth for them all. None of them dare admit it except Alice. General speaking, this movie has brought me a weird sensation, but I really cannot deny its authenticity. People sometimes just act as the four in the film. Who dares to believe in love anymore?

title: What is love, complicated or simple, beautiful or ugly?
review:
"Closer" tries to figure out what love is by drawing a love rectangle in front of audiences, which is not so uncommon in real life. But totally different from my expectation of one or two romantic stories with a happy ending, the movie renders me contemplation: is love complicated or simple, beautiful or ugly?

To Larry, love is absolutely selfish. He loves Anna, so he is outrageous and goes out of mind when knowing that Anna has cheated on him and falls in love with Dan. But instead of letting her go and perfecting that romance, he does anything to get Anna back and bind her firmly, including taking advantage of her guilt for him, even knowing that Anna will be living in pain. To Dan, love is possessive. No matter who he is with, Alice or Anna, he needs the woman to be one hundred percent loyal to him, both physically and mentally. When he knows that Anna has sex with Larry, as a compensation for the divorce, he feels betrayed, reluctant to cross the line. I figure whether he desires Anna because it seems beyond reach and when he can really be with Anna, he finds it no longer appealing to him. To Alice, a pretty stripper, love is pure, with nothing else involved. When she finally finds herself disappointed with Dan, she leaves without hesitation. To Anna, love is a luxury. She thinks that she doesn't deserve love, so she prefers to live with Larry, tortured by guilt and pain, rather than pursuing happiness. In sum, the movie is thought-provoking, well-done!

title: Love is not all beautiful
review: "Closer" tells a romance that is not romantic at all. The opening of the film is kind of deceptive. When Alice(by Natalie Portman) opens her eyes to see the handsome Dan(by Jude Law), I expect a romantic love story that is not quite practical but beautiful. And my expectation continues all the way through these two's trip around London until the scene in the studio of the photographer Anna(by Julia Roberts) comes up, and all the following part turns out that the film is about the pain, twistedness and ugliness of love and sex. Dan has a crush on Anna, and regardless of his relationship with Alice, he tries to seduce Anna(without avail at first). A greedy man who sees two kinds of beauty in women and wants to have them both--not so uncommon; but he really disgusts me when he, posing as Anna, engages in an online sex chat with Larry(by Clive Owen), and even arranges a date for them. Here I see a man letting out his desire for a woman in a real perverted way. To add more to my shock, the date turns out to be working for Larry and Anna! Anna somehow gives me the impression of an intelligent and mature woman, and why she gets herself involved in a relationship with Larry, who seems to be driven much more by sexual urges than love, still remains a puzzle to me. Dan and Larry are the two most contemptible heroes I have ever seen in a film. Their loves for Alice and Anna are entangled with obscenity and suspicion, even to a hysterical extent; on the other hand, the two heroines seem to be calm and rational, but somewhat weak and vulnerable to the men's brutal love. In the end, Larry manages to get back Anna, Alice seems to be free from all the mess, and Dan, although the busiest struggling in his love for two women, is left with nothing, not even the real name of the one who may once loved him the most. All in all, the story is ridiculous and makes no sense; well, maybe that is what the film is about: Love can be ridiculous and make no sense.

title: stunning exploration about love and sex
review:
Coming from a relative conservative country, i at first got shocked when watching the movie. the rectangle love between these two couples.it is not difficult to understand since such things happen a lot in big cities. however, what i saw in them and their love are vanity and empty. they are desperate for love while confused about love.when it finished, i kept thinking, what's true love? why are they so painful? i didn't get an answer from the movie.

in the movie, they were all talking about love. the word is too big and too confusing. man are too greedy. they make love so selfish and deceptive. i really agree that sometimes it's better not to tell your lover every detail that happen between you and your ex-boy or girl.

i think the movie has a very interesting ending. in fact i don't care about the truth very much. the only truth is that Alice has been trying her best to love and get love. though someone may find it disappointing, it's just the course.

the performance of them are good though i did care too much about my friends idol" Juliet Robots". she is very beautiful, but Alice impressed me most.

title: Brilliant In Almost Every Way
review:
People are weak and those that seem weakest might in fact be the strongest, you can't tell until the end.

In most American movies we are used to seeing strong characters that fall into certain simple categories, as if we are too stupid to understand that people on film can be like people in real life. Villains have to be wholly bad and heroes have to be flawed just enough to make them "likable" but still they are good through and through.

These people are more like people in real life. They are perhaps good at their jobs but otherwise weak, they change their mind, they mess with each other's heads, they say they love one person and they have sex with each other anyway or with a hooker and say it didn't mean anything (maybe it didn't). They love one person and want to be with them until they prove to be too demanding or needy then they turn or return to someone else who wants them.

Some characters fail when given a chance for greatness (Law's writer) and some have no career ambition and just want to live their life (Portman). The interplay between these people is riveting and the whole thing seems almost live, like watching a play.

I recommend this movie highly just for the interplay between the characters, which is really all this movie is about. There are no heroes or villains, just people.

title: And so it is
review:
Of the four protagonists in Closer, Clive Owen's Larry is perhaps the most direct...he likens his being with Julia Roberts' Anna as "the princess with the toad". Told that it is a frog, not a toad, he insists "toad". And as the movie continues, we realize that he was correctly describing himself right from the first, warts and all.

Two other people - Jude Law as the aptly named Dan Wolf - and Nathalie Portman as Alice, make up the rest of the quartet of characters who fall in and out of lust/love with each other over a period of years.

What bothers me most about many of the reviews here, is that people complain that people in Closer are unlikeable. Well, so what? Considering how many of us lie and cheat in love - often as much to ourselves as to others - how many of us are really all that attractive? The opening words of this film are from a song by Damien Rice, where he intones "And so it is..." He is singing about infatuation verging on obsession, which is what Closer is really about - the way we obsess about each other to the point of destroying both the love and ourselves; the closer we try to get, the further apart we become. We may insist on the truth, but how will we recognize it if it is not what we want so desperately to hear? Polished performances of a slickly intelligent and often witty script are searingly directed to perfection by Mike Nichols, who has been in this territory before with "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?". The main difference is that in that earlier film, George and Martha KNEW the difference between surface and reality, whereas the four lost souls of Closer wander myopically through the landscape of their lives looking for signposts. At the end of Virginia Woolf, they at least had each other. At the end of Closer, no-one seems to have anything left at all. Perhaps the main point of Closer is that our images of ourselves can only remain beautiful from a distance; the closer we get, the blurrier it all becomes. This is a sad film in the end, but it is also one of the most adult films ever to be made. After all, stories of princesses and frogs are really for children, aren't they?

title: Whatever
review:
Petty much 'porn' with the sex edited out (because it never happened?) then some losers trying to weave some feeling or sentiment out of:

1) water 2) bits of paper 3) exposures on chemical paper 4) 'wife' 5) truth 6) sex or the prospect of 7) pretty much gap-filling

Interesting use of pole-dance and fluorescent wig, wonder how anyone who investigates bodily balance can ever 'get it up' after the scene.

Unfortuate misinterpreted split personalities, accurate depiction of depression as being inter-personal as opposed to self-inflicted.

Sad for Alice as there was not so much a 'revenge sex' (is that ever possible?) as 'sympathy sex' (again, might not be possible but illustrative of vanity) or pretty much a 'head bang' (if one can sink low and be petty about it).

Good attempt to free an otherwise prisoner of conscience from a life of deceit. By freeing the 'prisoner' their captors were not truly free until they are assured that Alice's innocence was never tarnished but has developed depth of understanding.

Only useful part is where any losing of temper (controlled or otherwise) shows the real prisoner as the inability to admit the whole truth in the vain hope that they were actually 'helping someone'.

title: Intriguing, but too far removed from reality
review:
Mike Nichols' 2004 cinematic comeback "Closer" seems to be really poignant at first. The cast is great, the score suits the scenes fine and the dialog is sharp and witty. The problem is, after a while "Closer" becomes obviously far removed from reality. Characters start to act real quick-witted and theatrical dialog when in real life they would just walk away from each other in anger. Couples split and then get together for no convincing reason. And if that wasn't enough one character at one point exclaims that she's just fallen out of love in one instant. Just like that. As if anyone would ever say that.

The reason why I'm so critical about this lack of total realism is that "Closer" seems so much to try to make an universally true statement about love or male-female relationships. In that aspect it doesn't quite deliver and the lines aren't as poignant as the writer wished they'd be.

That's more of a fault of the original play, though. The movie, as an adaption of that play, is fine. The cast, as I've said, is consistently great and the scene, in which Clive Owen is fooled into thinking he's having an erotic chat with a girl is one of the funniest and truest things about modern society ever put on screen. "Closer" is worth seeing for that alone. Oh, and if you happen to be a heterosexual guy, the chance of seeing Natalie Portman with very, very little on might also be an inducement for watching this movie.

title: Frightening...and true
review: I'm happy for all those who saw the movie and did not recognize the characters, their problems and their "insane" way of dealing with them as coming from the real world. You live like angels. This film summed up beautifully everything sad and nasty and ugly and painful that I have ever encountered in my relationships and those whom I know, very real people. Lies, deceit, sleaziness, addiction, clinging to somebody who doesn't want you anymore, doing despicable things to get that somebody back in your life, acting on lust, shame, guilt, hurting and being hurt - best by those you love the most, I have seen them all. Just not all at the same time, condensed in two hours and played by four charismatic actors. It was frightening and well...did not cheer me up (to use a euphemism). And here comes the spoiler: At the end my soul felt sick, as grand as it may sound. The only healing line was Alice's "I don't love you anymore". And that just makes you even sadder.

title: If you believe in love stories, you must watch this.
review:
I bought the DVD sometime during 2004. But didn't see it after reading its review. But then one day on Holi I was getting bored when I saw this film. Taking into the fact that the same day I saw Nishabd and this movie matters a lot about my opinion about the movie.

The movie is too good. The movie elaborates about two couple who fall in love with the others wife. Alice is a stripper who gets paired up with Dan a unsuccessful novelist. Anna is an independent divorcée & owns a studio where she takes photos. Dan goes to her studio for a photo session and proposes to her but she rejects Dan because Dan already is going steady with Alice. Dan retaliates with fixing him with Larry. Then the story moves how Dan falls for Anna and Larry falls for Alice. But there is one thing very honest about their characters. They were honest with each other about their feelings.

Nice story, nice picturization. A must watch.

title: beautiful movie, I loved it!
review:
an absolute fav of mine.

I've seen it before, but yesterday I saw it again. wow. it is so realistic and ALIVE! the most beautiful scene when Natalie Walks down the street in New York with Damien rice singing the blowers daughter.. it is so beautiful that tears comes to my eyes. I really liked Clive Owen, have never seen him star somewhere before, but he blew me away. Julia Roberts plays very well, and a character that I am not used to see her in. Jude Law was good as always, but Natalie Portman was the star in this movie. her comments falls naturally from her mouth, like everybody could have said it in whatever situation, but I know that is not true. Stars to the scriptwriter, the story is good, original and unoriginal. it is unoriginal because it is so many normal situations, but it is original because it is not driven too far. Very good :)

title: Pretentious, ridiculous, but saved (kind of) by the actors and photography.
review:
Prior of seeing this movie I had heard every review and adjective possible about Closer. Erotic, realistic, challenging, smart, dumb, boring, exhilarating (however you spell it...), masterful or just plain beautiful. I watched the movie deciding to judge for myself, not knowing what to expect.

Closer is one of those many movies when after it has only just begun you think "not another classic love story." Sure enough there's the awaited love-at-first-sight sequence, between to beautiful people in the middle of a great big city full of strangers. But thankfully, it stops there, because we might accuse Closer of being many things, but it's neither unoriginal or boring.

I had only seen Primary Colors (excellent, especially Travolta) and Working Girl (not so excellent) from Mike Nichols before, and it was a surprise to see such an excellent photography, camera movement and just visual pleasure with so much simplicity. Continuing on the technical success, the actors are brilliant,I didn't imagine Natalie Portman this mature, and Clive Owen is a very pleasant surprise...

But that's it, nothing else to see here, because the interesting bit is over, the movie is well made, but there's nothing inside. I've seen people leave after 30 minutes, because apart from the occasional laugh (Owen especially), or the rare quote that speaks the real truth, the actors aren't enough to make us forget that this story is just plain ridiculous.

It's a romance for people who have it all wrong, guys who need to go out more, or just sex freaks. Because as much as I like sex, I don't believe perverts like these resemble the true animals inside of us. No, women don't like to be called whores, and facial ejaculation isn't common in every sexual intercourse like Roberts' character claims.

The directing is pretentious, it wants to make a glorified "art" film from he silliest screenplay ever (Hey guys, lets make an internet sex scene that goes on for 10 minutes). This is intellectual masturbation at it's finest. The screenwriter probably needs to stop dating crazy cum guzzling freaks, because that's the only thing portrayed in this "romance", love and sex are mixed in confusion, and we get to see breakups and cheating confessions. And then some more.

People claim that this movie is "so very real", to those, you either need to finally be in your first relationship, or just stop thinking sex is all that matters in one.

To those who like to watch movies just for the acting (like me), this is an interesting one, but please don't expect an ounce of emotion from the story. 7 out of 10 for those who fit in that category, 9 for the ones who need to understand a thing or two about their lives, and 5 for the rest. I give it a 6 because I'm not counting the second category.

My English may suck, but not as bad as this movie

title: How Disappointing
review: sometimes, a bad screenplay goes by and so much energy, time and effort is put into a negative black hole sucking karmic cosmicness only to remind us of what is good through what is not. Natalie Portman is wasted here. Julia is above such a film. although Jude Law acts well always, a wasted performance as well. simply a well produced miss. i hope we are stronger than what was on offer. i know we are. i am living it the other way. i am choosing the other path. i pray for my enemies. incredible that Mike Nichols chose to direct this sorry sag as he did 'angels in America' a few years ago with Pacino and Streep and that is a work of divine intervention. Ti's easy to make your fellow man feel bad. challenge your self to shine light with out withholding the truth of life. whether in art or reality. good luck

title: What happens when a potential 4some orgy becomes a relationship!
review: I didn't like this film. It was a very good film, but I didn't like it. Maybe as I grow older and I re-watch it in, I will understand it better and like but for now, I saw it and it was borderline silly. The film takes place in London, England. Julia Roberts plays a famous photographer who is with Clive Owen's character but their relationship is forever altered when she meets Jude Law's character and begins to sleep with him. Jude law's character is, by the way, with a new American import by way of Natalie Portman in her Oscar nominated role. Add in a few sexual situations, tons of bad language and innuendos, Natalie Portman wearing a pink wing and working as stripper whom Clive Owen's character comes on to and you've pretty much got the much hyped movie Closer.

title: Not bad (for a Nichols' film)
review:
A failed writer, a young stripper, a doctor with a certain prestige, and a very successful photographer. Four characters, four crossed relationships. Sex, love, infidelity, the animal attraction... Well, "Closer" is not that original, is it? Cinema has talked about all kind of relationships along the last 100 years. So, the virtues of "Closer" are not in the story it tells but in the way Nichols tells it, his last movie is much more foul-mouthed and direct than the rest of his works. Is rather strange to hear Julia Roberts holding a conversation with huge explicitly sexual contents, or to watch strait-laced Natalie Portman moving like an expert stripper.

Well, I don't think Mike Nichols is a great director, and I don't specially like none of the actors either, but the movie as a whole is not that bad... As we use to say here in Spain: in blind men's land, the one-eyed is the king (got it?).

*My rate: 7/10

title: Hang in there, I told myself
review: "Closer" (2004): Jude Law, Natalie Portman, Juia Roberts, and, I'm sorry, I've forgotten the name of the other male lead, with Mike Nichols directing. As the film got rolling, I felt I was seeing too many plot and character clichés. "Why am I being shown all this?" I asked myself. "Hang in there," I told myself, "it'll clarify itself." By god, it did. We are presented with four strangers who meet under completely random circumstances, and begin pursuing artificial relationships...but like a Rubic's Cube, every time they seem to have "sided"  gotten CLOSER  they each, in their own pathetic, well-crafted fashion, set about to ruin it. Do I see a progression towards honest self-awareness? Hmm...I think so. "Hang in there," I told myself. Then they twist the Cube again. "Maybe THIS is it this time," I ponder. While watching "Closer", I went from ambivalence to thinking it was quite good.

title: Extreme Characterizations
review:
"Closer" is a film about four people and the role that truth (or different kinds of truth) plays in their relationships as they try to get closer to themselves and to each other. The mixed reaction from viewers is because while "Closer" is a nicely packaged film and a fast-paced intelligent screenplay; the four main characters are "extremes" or at least extreme examples of the behaviors at the allegorical core of the film. These "expressionistically" drawn characters offend and disappoint the viewer segment expecting realistic and sympathetic portrayals (insert "characters with whom they can identify" here).

But they are extreme because they are intended to illustrate (in obvious ways) certain subtle elements of our romantic relationships. The two male characters, Dan (Jude Law) and Larry (Clive Owen), are products of and participants in the most fundamental Darwinian courtship process. Despite making a pretense of having evolved from the competitive courtship of male primates, they are still driven more by the need to win and secure a trophy than by a quest to love. Likewise Anna, the older female (Julia Roberts), is attracted by the male demonstrations of dominance, both the physical bluster of strength and the mental head games intended to manipulate her emotions. Accordingly her behavior encourages these demonstrations by the males.

Contrasted with these three is the younger female (Natalie Portman) who seeks a man who can transcend primitive drives, loving her and allowing her to love him.

Into this mix writer Patrick Marber inserts the truth factor in an ironic way. Portman's character places little value on words, adopting a false name at the beginning of the film. That she is superficially living a lie is ironic because she is the only one of the four who does not lie about their true feelings or engage in self-deception. Her transparency and detached self-awareness is symbolized by her job as a stripper.

The other three torture themselves and each other with superficial truths while engaging in compulsive deception about their actions and actual feelings, to each other and to themselves. Their duplicity is symbolized by their occupations. Dan is an obit writer, skilled in the use of euphemisms to disguise the unflattering characteristics of the deceased. Anna is a photographer, skilled in freezing a single moment in time uncharacteristic of the actual subject she is representing. Larry is a dermatologist focused on the superficial surface that one publicly presents.

The key exchange occurs early in the film as Alice and Dan discuss how essential euphemisms are in his job: Alice: What would my euphemism be? Dan: She was... disarming. Alice: That's not a euphemism. Dan: Yes, it is.

Alice's up-front and open behavior causes him to let down his guard and feel a higher level of emotion, but his need to make new conquests and to test his attractiveness soon reasserts itself. She is willing to forgive this until finally convinced that he cannot transcend something so much a part of his basic nature. With that realization she falls out of love.

"Closer" is much like "XX/XY" in its exploration of the mysteries of male discontent although it is philosophically deeper and much better written. Coles (Mark Ruffalo) plays the Dan character in that film, but Law's portrayal is more convincing because he does not have to alternate between rebel and wimp, something that Ruffalo could not quite pull off.

All four performances are solid although Roberts is given very little with which to work. Portman is especially good. The problem with "Closer" is that its symbolic message is not getting through to most viewers (at least it would appear so from the many clueless reviews and comments) who try to relate to it on a literal level. But if you like abstract tales deceptively showcased in a realistic package you should really enjoy this fine film.

Then again, what do I know? I'm only a child.

title: not bad...
review: I think the history is not very well built and results too much absurd. Despite that, actors work is really good, and, from my point of view, that saves the quality of the film. The story advances in a strange way, with changes in time that are not shown to us until some time later, so usually,it is difficult to understand WHEN it's happening after the end of the scene. In addition, the characters claim to believe in love and loyalty, but they don't think in nothing more than sex, sex and sex. The director has not done a good work, nor the writer, on the other hand, actors made a great part, (specially both men, including one nomination to the Oscar's), actor's work is, by far, the best part of the film, if they were not so good, film would be too much bad. It is not strange that is well marked by kids, because they only catch the sex part so they are pleased, but it is usual that they don't catch the complicated personality of the characters and why they do those things, so it is not strange, also, that older people, more used to think about it, think that is a worse film. a 6, it's not bad, neither good.

title: The play plays well.
review: The twists and turns of coincidence and rivalry are Shakespearean. The acting is superb. The cast is an intriguing mixture of British masculinity and American femininity. As the final credits turned, I was stunned at my own lack of awareness during the film that it was indeed a cast of four, performing a well written play, based in excellent dialog. The play indeed plays well in the movie. I was particularly entertained by the unusual nature of parts played by Natalie Portman and Jude Law. She uncharacteristically plays a sex worker of sorts. He uncharacteristically plays a neurotic underachiever. Their chemistry and dissonance is well done. And who doesn't like to watch Julia Roberts and/or Clive Owen being sexually tortured and/or torturing? Something for everyone there. My only negative criticism is that some of the plot devices bringing them all together seemed a bit arcane, despite being gussied up in sexy gear.

title: Decent...and oddly erotic...
review: This is a disturbing movie to those of us for whom the grass always appears greener on the opposite side of the fence. Beware! You may end up with no grass at all. It also points out excellently how we males haven't quite been able to shed that 'woman as property' mentality. Another man gives our current love a night of extreme pleasure...BEFORE we were together...and it disturbs us enough to destroy the entire relationship? For shame...hunt the guy up, buy him a beer and thank him. Jude Law played the role perfectly. It also demonstrates that we men are NOT the only ones unable at times to make up our minds on what it is we want. The Julia Roberts character flitted back and forth from bed to bed during the entire movie...and in her final scene, as she settles under the covers at night, you see it in her eyes...she still has regrets. Julia Roberts and Natalie Portman, through the forced explanations of the details of their lovemaking by their less secure male partners, become much more human and desirable because of it. This movie demonstrates perfectly that NONE of these characters are ready for a long term relationship, let alone a marriage. Word to the wise; If you and your lover are on shaky ground, this movie could well push you one way or the other.

title: Haunting
review:
I love films that haunt, and this one certainly does. We have the writer, the dermatologist, the photographer and the ex-stripper (now coffee house server), four characters who are entwined in each others lives by couplings that are traditional and not so traditional.

There isn't too much of a plot but there doesn't need to be; it's all about some very honest dialog and emotions. It puts you in a "What would you do in this situation mode", forcing you to react and think as these people. The acting was superb and you have a hard time forgetting that this is just a film and not a reality show of these four people.

Speaking for myself, I was deeply moved. The opening song was so beautiful and gripping. I don't have many soundtracks in my music collection, but this one I must have. It was definitely worth seeing but those people who don't want to feel too deeply should probably avoid since it will be wasted on them.

title: Jane.....
review: Jane to me is the most compelling character...I probably had more ideas on her after seeing the movie but I haven't seen it in about a month, so I'll try to go with my memory...At the beginning,Jane looks very young-like a rebellious child. The only person who seemed to notice her in the crowd was Dan. She did not really know what love was-she was searching. Before and after she was with Dan, she was a stripper. But while she was with him, she was not..she worked as a waitress. She had made the comment in the movie, "lying is the most fun a girl can have without taking her clothes off". This is interesting because it almost implies when she is not a stripper, she lies. And when she is with Dan, she is not a stripper... Coincidence? Perhaps...Because later when she is a stripper again, she is truthful about her own identity...almost like her stripping of her clothes is symbolic of her also stripping herself of the lies. She is a different person with Dan, but perhaps it is easier that way, because she can experiment with love from a different perspective, so she could keep a cool head. It seems like she has done this with every relationship in her life, because in the book Dan wrote about her, she tells Larry that it is about her but leaves out the truth. When she fell in love with Dan, she became needy, something that wouldn't fly with him because he was so needy himself. He needed someone to take care of him, not someone who needed taken care of. This taught Jane a very important lesson-not to lose yourself in love. However, she needed Dan to do something to make her not regret leaving him, so she got him angry to the point he hit her, and it let her know that the love was a farce and allowed her to move on with her life. At the end of the movie, she appears to be so self confident and sure of herself and her feelings, so different than at th beginning, and this shows because instead of one man who is constantly seeking love noticing her, every man is almost mesmerized by her. She had completedher journey.

title: Umm!! Yes, No , Maybe , he loves me she loves (Maybe not)?!?
review:
When I watched this movie , the opening scene seemed to indicate a silly romantic movie, but actually it has interesting features and attempts to discuss human love relationships.

The underlying theme seemed to want to show that to sell yourself does not necessarily mean you have to be a stripper or someone who exhibits themselves as such, but might be a respectable artist/photographer who appears composed and presentable.

Some parts were unbelievable like falling in love with some you take to the hospital?!?!?! Another unbelievable aspect was the capriciousness of the characters feelings except for Alice. She seems to be the only one who had true feelings for Dan whereas everybody else seemed to be able to jump into bed with everyone else at a whim. That I think downgraded my score for this movie.

What I did find extremely interesting and probably strikes a note with most men is when both male characters have confrontations with the female characters and incessantly and destructively prise out information about whether they had sex with the other party. The interesting thing was were both female characters willingly volunteer that they enjoyed the sex and both indicate that by saying " I came.." . This was a damning admission to both male characters and I think is probably indicative of male possessiveness which is only natural. The female characters ended up being the battleground for the two male protagonists. What I don't know is if the female characters were just being honest or taunting the other party. Their reactions are interesting where Alice just leaves and Anna returns to Larry. I think Alice had more self respect than Anna after such humiliation.

Overall the movie didn't quite make the grade, but the subject is an interestingly mature and adult one

title: "Closer" is a thought-provoking film about the psychology of intimate relationships
review: I found "Closer" to be a fine, thought-provoking film. It seems to be about theprimarily--men's obsession with talking about sex and finding new partners and their willingness to have sex behind their partner's backs, while revealing their (unfair) fury and voyeurism when they think the object of their desires, their female partners, might be doing the same. The movie resonated with what I know about a certain type of male insecurity: the I-must-conquer-every-attractive-woman-I meet syndrome, not matter how loving and strong my current relationship is, but don't let my partner have a screw behind my back because I will become jealous, voyeuristic, and rageful. The men appeared to be constantly testing their partners, another reflection not only of the men's insecurities but also their nervous projection onto the women of what the men themselves were doing or plotting to do. Making this all happen via the careful plot twists and turns between the four people was very effective and suspenseful. Ultimately, I wondered why all four didn't get together as a quadruple, since one could make the case that they found each other all very attractive. While overtly each character appears very heterosexual, I felt strong homosexual attractions going on. The title is perfect. All the many ways each couple in turn tried to create close, loving relationships, but because of their insecurities and betrayals, they never could stay faithful long enough to pull it off. Nor did the voyeuristic and verbal assaults the men made on their partners over suspicions concerning their other love lives do anything to improve the closeness of any relationship, far from it.

title: More realistic than most of us care to admit
review: Although this movie was not quite what I expected, I found it to be a very realistic view of what relationships can be. I think that most of us can relate to at least one of the characters, whether it is a real life scenario or just a thought we might have. I think that Natalie Portman's character was the most interesting. She always seems to bring the perfect attitude to a film no matter what the genre. This movie is not for the faint of heart, especially if you are offended by VERY strong language. It is not a love story with a fairy tale ending, but then again, neither are most of the real life relationships!!! I think that this movie hits a nerve and makes us all realize that we are human and subject to "falling from grace". It is how we pick ourselves up that makes our character.

title: Easy to respect,tough to like
review:
This film,about the revolving relationships between two couples,is a very heady and strong effort by all involved,but it is tough to feel much sympathy or likability for nearly everyone involved. Julia Roberts' Anna can't seem to be trusted to hold onto a relationship,Jude Law's Dan can't be trusted to do the right thing once in one,Clive Owen's Larry is a thick-headed professional sort who can't seem to decide whether or not he's truly in love with either Annd or Alice,and Natalie Portman's Alice(probably the most sympathetic of the bunch)is so fragile and delicate that she's always on the verge of dropping a relationship at the turn of an emotion.

I've read one review that says that this movie is "as real as it gets". Really? How many random foursomes of people in a large city(in this case,London)constantly go pin-balling back and forth between each other,regardless of the fact that they are both so cruel to each other in the first place? I would wager that here are very real elements of real life relationships in this movie,but as a whole,the personal dynamics of this film are much more convoluted than what you would ordinarily get in a true life interchange of couples.

The acting is strong,and the writing seems better suited for the stage. Certainly not bad enough to give a low rating,but not worth a rave,either.

title: Did I miss something?
review:
And only I give it an 8 because of Clive Owen. He's such a man and a woman's man. He can be funny, sexy, and so on. Why did I buy this movie, because one, no one would go to the movies with me to see it and two I was lead to believe by some interview that there was a sex scene in the movie between Clive and Julia. But it's not in the DVD. So was I cheated. Can someone who saw the movie on screen tell me if the DVD ripped me off? Then I will be very very angry with my husband and anyone else I asked who had no desire to see it. Thanks for any info. Or did I buy an R rated DVD that short changed me and so I will take it back for the real thing.

Lisa

title: Closer (4/5 stars)
review:
Synopsis: This is the story of four individual who cross paths, cross lovers, and ultimately screw themselves (and let me tell you: that is totally Nichol's element). It begins with Dan (Law) and Alice's (Portman) chance meeting, and soon enough they fall in love. Of course this does not last long because a photographer, Anna (Roberts), catches the eye of Dan and thus they have an affair. Shortly after this Daniel decides to tell Alice of the affair and he does it with such dry emotion that one cannot help but think he is the scum of the earth. However, he is not alone, Anna decides to tell her husband, Larry (Owen), that she has been having the affair as well. This scene is even more gut-wrenching. The betrayal and deception that occurs between these people is so incredible hurtful that it even grazes the viewer. Anyway, Alice decides to revert back to her old ways and join a strip club again. As fate would have it the distraught Larry shows up at this very strip club. Alice and Larry decide that perhaps it would be beneficial if they had a "go" at it, and not too mention it would definitely hurt their ex-lovers. And that is what this whole film is about: lovers turning into haters (I know that sounds ghetto but it's true). Almost everyone knows what it is like to be betrayed by a close loved one and the feelings of revenge that go with it. The only difference between us and the people in this film is that that these people decide to actually extract this vengeance. Well, oddly enough Anna leaves Dan and goes back to Larry, but Alice remains at the strip club. As one can imagine, Daniel is completely broken by this and so he confronts Larry about Anna: he wants her back. It is here that Larry tells him to go back to Alice, and so he tells Daniel where he can find her. Dan is overjoyed by Larry's display of compassion and thanks him for disclosing Alice's location. It is here where I found to be one of the cruelest things throughout the whole movie. Just before Dan leaves, Larry stops him and tells him with pride that he slept with Alice; Dan is devastated. The viewer suddenly feels the deception that Dan felt: Larry appeared to be so forgiving and so nice, and like Dan we forgive him, but when he utters this, we want to cry with Dan. Why on earth would Larry tell Dan this?! Simple: he wants revenge, and it is this revenge that shows us how cruel humans can be. At any rate Dan and Alice never really do get back together (although they do try), and Anna and Larry remain married. And that is the end of the movie. So what do we have to take away from it? Well, many things but what I took away was that love hurts and if we are not careful we can ruin the blessings that are bestowed upon us. These characters will never be the same again (even though Anna and Larry salvaged their marriage one can tell that the love they used to have is gone), and yet at one time they had everything they could have wanted. So why did these people do these things to each other? Well, it was a combination of: lust, jealousy, and rage. Those three little words ruined the lives of four people, and we as the viewer should always remember this. Because if there is anything a great movie like "Closer" can do, it is to have us take a second look at what we have and either try to change it or be thankful for it. In my opinion this film does the latter, and I couldn't be happier for the reminder. I really enjoyed this cathartic experience and therefore I will give "Closer": 4 out of 5 stars.

NOTE: 1/5 stars = bad 2/5 stars = OK 3/5 stars = good 4/5 stars = great 5/5 stars = classic

title: Can a film's score be based on whether you want to watch it again?
review:
Not the greatest movie I've ever seen, but oddly, something makes me want to watch it again. I don't really even know why - it's not too believable, the way the characters fall in and out of love at the drop of a hat, and it's not all that well written, either. The movie does make you think, though: What really is THE TRUTH, and IF there is such a thing to a relationship, and IF it is in fact knowable, WOULD you or DO you really want to know it?

Perhaps questions such as these are at the core of what is haunting about this film. Natalie Portman gives a really good performance, Jude Law a bit less so, but still manages to keep you engaged with his character. Frankly, they could have substituted just about anyone for Julia Roberts and had just as good a product.

Damien Rice's song, "The Blower's Daughter" provides a brilliant punctuation to the beginning and end - they should have used even more of his work.

title: Unbelievable !
review: Mike Nichols is back. Great movie! Great acting! Great script! The best Mike Nichols's movie since "the graduate" with Dustin Hoffman. For sure this movie does not have anything less than the movies which have been nominated to the Academy awards. I can't tell anything about the story and I don't know how spend my ten lines. I just can say that it is a movie about love and cheating but without sin. If you are intrigued by that this is your movie. If you like a good, really classic, based on a good script cinema you'll love this movie. I missed it at the theater, I was not sure if rent it,I was wrong,I saw it on DVD, I loved it. If you are too much prude or you are scandalized from some bad word don't watch it.....is rated R.

title: good performances, but flat movie
review: Can you like a movie where all four lead characters are unlikable? The characters played by Julia Roberts, Jude Law, Clive Owens, and Natalie Portman are all selfish and unpleasant. All four actors are very good in their respective roles. However, there is a sense of detachment from these characters. For example, do you really care if Jude Law ends up with Julia Roberts and Natalie Portman (I should have such problems)? The ending is predictably dark, as you would expect it to be. It is easy to see why this well was critically acclaimed, but did not do well at the box office. Clive Owens and Natalie Portman deserved their Oscar nominations for their roles. However, if you are looking for a good time at the movies, look elsewhere. An interesting but wildly overpraised film. 5/10

title: Better than brilliant....
review:
After reading several of your user comments about "Closer," most of which seem to consider it brilliant, I have nothing to add except I found the film better than that, better, in fact, than any movie in memory that deals with sex and "romantic love." It is a masterwork which will linger in the collective consciousness as long as there are movies about sex and "romantic love," a concept which is revealed here to be as false as it is irresistible.

The Mike Nichols' production, with Julia Roberts, Natalie Portman, Clive Owen and Jude Law, tells a story, set in London, about two couples who change partners ("Won't you change partners and dance with me?") and change again over a four-year period, during which time they betray each other and themselves with splendid brutality and merciless alacrity.

These marvelous actors create ensemble performances which rank among the best ever committed to film. Their characters are highly intelligent, articulate, sexy and only interested in self-gratification. In other words, people just like you and me.

The wonderful screenplay, with its lacerating, biting wit, and brutal honesty, is by Patrick Marber and based on his play of the same title.

It more than matches up with "Who's Afraid of Virgina Wolfe?" which it has been compared to.

Those benighted souls who might complain about the language in "Closer," should be condemned to perpetual reruns of "The Sound of Music" in Bushland U.S.A. Those who crave better than brilliant direction, dialog and performances, can do no better than "Closer" and reruns of "Closer."

title: I'm Just Not Big Enough To Forgive You... Buster.
review:
having watched this movie in two separate sittings, it can easily be called a two-parter film. an emotional roller-coaster from boy meets girl with dreams love movie to twisted scheming adultery sex fest. Its definitely something new quite a new turn for some of the actors in the movie like Natalie Portman

The characters, while only four each perform vividly in their roles. Natalie (Alice) plays an aspiring American stripper who meets Jude Law (Dan) on her tour around London. Dan plays is a writer who uses Alice as inspiration to his book. the book is then read by Julia Roberts (Anna) who also falls in love with him. The final character Clive Owen (Larry), a perverted doctor, is thrown in by Dan on an anonymous fake internet date, setup by Dan in attempt to get back at Anna for not wanting an affair with him. Seems like your typical love story romance right? the one where it all works out in end and everyone finds the right person. Exactly huh? Not quite, as we find out. There's more to the picture than the character lead on to be.

not unlike Larry in the movie, my original intention in seeing this movie was as the previews showed, Natalie Portman As A Stripper! Can't miss seeing Star Wars's Queen Amadala in the buff, of course. When friends told me about this, their reaction was nothing like i had suspected. One of my friends said she nearly wanted to kill herself, another said she would never again watch it, that it was extremely difficult to watch. Had they seen the first half and walked out for some reason they'd go home with the warm happy feeling that all things will turn out and we'll get the cinema romance we paid to watch. Don't get me wrong, it is definitely worth seeing but the twists midway through this movie make this stand out as very Very different from a lot of other movies.

Its controversial, daring, and very different from a lot of other romance movies ever made. Cruel Intentions also has similar characters but none well-defined as the ones in Closer. The movie is definitely for adults and it worth seeing as a date movie. Very different, but also very good.

title: closer to my reality
review:
it began with a casual "hello,stranger." big time affair. cheating here and there. flings and flirts.

what would you think when you just flirt with someone else big time the moment before you hop into bed and snuggle into your lover's arms?

what would be more miserable than having to say sweet nothings and lots of "i love you's" to your lover when in fact you just had greater and more exciting sex with your fling awhile ago?

what if every time, every single time you have to decide between a lover and a fling, knowing that maybe, just maybe, your lover is one of the greatest things ever happen to you, while your fling makes your days more colorful and constantly makes dozen of butterflies in your belly?

what if you make the right choice, leaving your fling and be with your lover and daydreaming about living happily ever after, which only lasts for about,say, a year, then you can't stop thinking of your so-called-unfinished relationship with your fling, then still sneaking around to meet up,having sex and everything,and dealing with the same big old triangle all over again?

what if you make the wrong choice, leaving your lover who truly loves and admires you just as you are, to your lifetime-fling who's also somebody's baby,and ten times more challenging and appearing so incredibly out of reach to you?

said sadly, you got nothing in the end.

and oh, don't forget 'the blower's daughter' by Damien Rice in the beginning and end of film. (with 'can't take my eyes off you' stuck in your head. very nice.)

title: Not quite up to the script
review:
It's so rare that we get to see a film made by adults for adults, that it's a pity to report that Mike Nichols's Closer doesn't quite come up to the very high standards that Patrick Marber sets for it. Marber's screenplay, adapted from his own stage version, is full of verbal sparrings which invite over-playing, and I think Nichols's deliberate attempt to under-emphasise the carnality of what takes place, letting the words work for the actors, so to speak, is what lets the film down. For once, I think that the script could do with more opening up from its theatrical origins, taking the action out of rooms, apartments, studios. The music is also spartan (which I would normally welcome), leaving the dialogue with much to do. The camera work is mostly static and head and shoulder, allowing for the very remorseless examination of the characters' reactions and motives which the script demands, but making for a one-dimensional experience.

For such a distraction-free approach to work to succeed in the cinema (the closeups may be softened by smaller screens), performances need to be of the highest order. In this case, though none of the A-list actors by any means let themselves down, their characters' duplicity and self-deception does not transfer from dialogue to action. The only clear motive that we see expressed is for Natalie Portman's character to leave (having had an unambiguous slap from Clive Owen); but earlier, we are asked to believe that Clive will have the hots for Natalie (because he suddenly strokes her face), and that the Julia Roberts character will deceive Clive for Jude Law because they stop talking and start kissing during a photographic session. Oh, and Julia and Clive will get married, but their initial meeting (contrived by Jude, or accidental ?) intimated no such thing.

The result, as many people have commented, is that we find it hard to care very much about these four people and their love and sex lives, to the point where the one (love) and the other (sex) become inter-changeable. Tellingly, though the characters repeatedly ask each other to be truthful, demanding not so much faithfulness as full reporting, it's hardly surprising that neither they nor we understand what has happened. Rather than the intended dissection of relationships, we get an intimate but unrewarding closeup of four characters doing things that come of as much a surprise to them as it is to us.

It's a pity that four such able actors have been reined in to such an extent. For what might be tantrums and breakdowns we get a series of tautly scripted two- and three-handers, with never so much a spilt glass of wine to break the rhythm. Julia Roberts's performance is better than she usually is allowed to be (how she must long for parts such as this), and Natalie Portman shows just how much potential she has for the more fully developed roles to come. Jude Law is good in a bookish sort of way, but is once more not allowed to (or maybe can't) work over much against his looks. He also needs to stop walking like that (the first time I have noticed how ungainly he is). Clive Owen is a bit of a disappointment, perhaps because his anger and spite, not to mention lust, bangs so hard against the other three.

I was not shocked or disgusted by what these fickle four get up to, or say to each other.
