One thing I did find irritating was that both the female characters were stunning while both the male characters were... not. I guess they're acting compensated though. All veterans of the big screen, they all performed incredibly in what was undoubtedly one of the most challenging and demanding roles I assume they would ever have to do. Even if you have had no previous experience in this particular area of life, a little thing we call love, the way in which you know the turmoil and the pain that is tearing the characters apart little by little, is astounding.

A stunning movie where reality comes to the big screen. Love hurts. Thats life. This movie nearly missed a 10 from me for only one reason: I like a happy ending. I can't help it.

Brilliant but not something which helps you sleep easy at night.

title: Deepest truth, naturally real
review:
Well. I won't be able to describe my feelings about this film because my English is not enough. I wonder if my Hungarian is...

So in three words: it was marvelous. I definitely liked this film. It's the best lately. I haven't seen such a good film in months. Every minute I felt like I saw myself and I would have done the same thing they did. (And I already did and felt things like those) The play is great. All the actors were very touching. I could feel their misery in me. The other thing: music is superb. I especially like Jem - Come on closer but the others are great as well. It's a pity there isn't an OST. This is definitely a must see film.

title: And so it is...
review: Mike Nichols' version of the play "Closer" is one of 2004s most engrossing films with its sharp dialogue and astonishing performances. Everything about this film cuts to the core of the viewer. We watch as two couples, both formed by chance meetings find themselves involved in adultery and manipulation. Each character claims to love their companion, but at the same point they are willing to use them for sexual gratification and deceit. The performances by Jude Law, Julia Roberts and Natalie Portman are sterling. However, the best comes from Clive Owen who delivers his dialogue with such ferocity that he strikes at the audience as well. You cannot help but be taken aback by how emotionally charged and powerful Owen's acting iscertainly worth his award for Best Supporting Actor at the Golden Globes and his Oscar nomination, as well.

title: Good for those that experienced something similar
review: Closer has made a huge impression on me because of its strong resemblance to my life experiences. It's about four people who don't really know what exactly they want in life. After watching it, I couldn't talk for 15 minutes. It was the only movie that I actually cried over. The song "Blower's Daughter" is very touching, too. I would recommend this movie for those who had some bad relationships in their life. The movie really captures the essence of life, in my view. Some might find it to be a bit trashy and maybe even stupid. However, I think that it is very perceptive. The performances are OK, and the costumes are great. Natalie Portman really comes through in this movie. To summarize: the movie is very poignant and well made, you should definitely go see it if you feel like crying (=

title: Poor Jude
review: Jude Law gives another strong performance in an otherwise turgid piece of artless ham. Patrick Marber's script contains the sort of 'state of the nation' drivel which was popular amongst literary types in the nineties. It has not aged well. An excruciating piece of Brit-flick 'product', mistaking profundity for profanity, heavy on histrionics and sexual confrontation; an egregious and deeply unconvincing portrait of a London which does not exist outside of the shallow self-referential imagination of the enormously smug Marber. The judgement of the picture's stars must now forever be held in doubt. Jude Law manages to inject some charm and amiability into a role which appears designed solely to humiliate him. Clive Owen (disappointing since Croupier) is a sort of uber-Nic Cage, but overplays the machismo of his stock-in-trade to the near brink of comedy. Natalie Portman is faintly disturbing as the barely legal pole dancer and American enigma. The film is saved by the music of Damien Rice, which provides the first and last scenes with an emotional integrity otherwise entirely absent. But the decision to use The Smiths' How Soon Is Now as the elevator accompaniment to Clive and Natalie's strip club showdown will provoke righteous indignation amongst Morrissey fans. The lyrics are much, much better than the lines the actors are paid to recite.

title: Best film of the year
review: For the first time in years a true ensemble picture has been seen on the the big screen. There were no superfluous characters like in Gosford Park or other such lauded "ensemble" pictures, instead, four well rounded, detailed rich characters who command our attention and compassion throughout the film. The performances were incredible. Jude Law was able to convey weakness and pomposity, Julia Roberts (her best performance EVER) was both selfish and self loathing and academy award nominations for Clive Owen and Natalie Portman serve as the praise for their masterful portrayals. I was mesmerized from beginning to end, with everything from the script to the execution of the actual storytelling. The exclusion of this film from the best picture category, and the inclusion of the cutesy Neverland, shows that the academy is not watching enough movies.

title: closer to the heart
review: This film is prove that good acting, dialogue and a good story will have you glued to your seat for two hours making your money worth. Its plot is dialogue driven, and the performances are spectacular, especially Clive Owen who brings his character to reality in a level that the other big names do not achieve, perhaps it was because I keep thinking of the other actors in their other most famous performances. This movie is about as real as it gets when you deal with relationships. It left me with a though, and made me compare my own relations, remembering where are humans and that our feelings are very strong and drive us, sometimes to our doom. Excellent film, no special effects, no at an epic score, just good acting, excellent dialogue, a Must see for film lovers.

title: Closer Winners!
review: Closer stands out as one of the most powerful and riveting movies of the year marked by awesome performance deliveries. Clive Owen and Natalie Portman just snagged Golden Globes, and justly so. So many responses are pouring out on this message board that this movie is "garbage." I can only assume there's got to be correlation between hating this movie and voting for Bush. I think most of America wasn't ready for Closer, and was shocked by it. I just love how raw emotions can be portrayed so well. This movie is intimate, passionate, and raw. Not for all, but for those who just want to let go. Closer... it's good, and you need to see it if you want something outside the boring box

title: Relationships in Turmoil
review: "Closer" is a very dynamic film. It illustrates the turmoil of two relationships that are steeped in love at first site. Natalie Portman Alice, gives another perfect performance that even surpasses the prior one in "Garden State". Jude Law is excellent as the doting acquaintance who develops amorous click with his professional photographer, Anna, played by Julia Roberts. Clive Owen, plays Larry, the dermatologist who is duped into this original triangle by Law's character. Indeed, the duping on the chat room via the computer is a humorous comment on today's writing atmosphere. Jude Law plays a writer of an obituary column who is elevated to editor only because of the death of his predecessor. There is raw sexual exhibition in a London strip club. The story if dynamic. Mike Nichols has directed another winner. He has maintained his successful ability to communicate in film. Bravo to this cinema.

title: Modernity, loves, lies and betrayals
review:
Absolutely top class film, sold out for the second night running when I saw it, which is remarkable for a converted stage play. A chance encounter brings failed writer Dan (Jude Law) and ex-stripper Alice (Natalie Portman) together in London. Their relationship revitalises Dan, who writes a book about her, but soon his affections are straying towards divorcée photographer Anna (Julia Roberts), soon to be involved with cynical dermatologist Larry (Clive Owen) as a result of a revenge-joke played by Dan. The film plots over 4 years of their turbulent inter-relationships, their loves, betrayals, lies, defections, break-ups and reunions.

The cast shone in their roles, the characters carefully constructed so as to attract your fleeting sympathies in one moment, only to be rudely dashed by some horrible act the next, meaning your affections can never settle on a single individual, and dismissing the capacity for moral judgement -- this is a story about real modernity and the flawed, fucked-up characters who inhabit it, the weakness, fallibility and flaws of human passions. Even Larry, played brilliantly by Clive Owen, who is probably the most repugnant of the characters simply for his calculating ability to play the game and succeed, is not without his sympathetic moments, despite his 'caveman' tendencies. Julia Roberts played a very unusual role as washed-out Anna; whilst Al thought her acting was slightly implausible, my view was that Anna's personality was intended to be 'thin', a piece of debris that floats between and is buffeted by various encounters and disasters, hardly in control of her own fate, led by impassioned men. Paul informs me that Owen and Portman have been nominated for all the awards for Closer, but the nominations could easily have been extended to Jude Law (currently the hardest-working actor in Hollywood, surely) and quite possibly to Julia Roberts as well.

Sterling stuff - not affective or life-affirming in the way of a typical Hollywood 'story of romance and passion' as the film has been billed (rather dishonestly, resulting in its surprisingly large audiences), but engrossing, moving, intriguing - a razor-sharp incision into the human condition that asks how much we really know the people we think we love.

Recommended!

title: Hate it or Love it!
review: Truly an amazing film, certainly not easy to watch at times, but when is life easy to bear at times? This is a movie where if you are able to relate any of it to your life, it just blows you away. It certainly makes you rethink what you are doing in your own relationships. On the other hand if you can't relate, then you can appreciate the fine acting. A film where Natalie Portman finally comes into her own, and sheds the Star Wars make-up. Julia Roberts seems to be heading in this "Indie" film direction, lately in her career. This was a sure fire win for her. I also enjoyed Clive Owen's disturbing performance. I found myself comparing him with a lot of guys I know, and deep down her represents what a lot of guys are thinking and wanting at times. Jude Law would be the likely main character that we all can relate to, guy or gal. The direction is fantastic, and the soundtrack is haunting. Give it a shot, and stay open minded.

title: Life goes easy on me...most of the time.
review: "Closer" is the story of three self-loathing Londoners and the American waif that turns their lives upside down. Natalie Portman's "Alice" comes to London from New York with very little money and no where to go. She meets Jude Law's "Dan" on a busy street during his morning commute to work at a London Newspaper where he writes for the Obits page. He had the dream of becoming a writer, but he isn't any good at it, he has no voice and no ideas. Alice and Dan fall in love, she moves into his flat, and he writes a book based on her remarkable and highly sexualized 21 year old life. He gets published and he goes to a photographer to get his picture taken for the book jacket. Dan falls in love with Julia Robert's photog, but the recently divorced "Anna" rejects his advances out of a sense of patriotism, and because she "is not a thief". And we are introduced to the sex-addicted dermatologist "Larry" while he is chatting on an internet casual sex club website. He later meets Anna at the London Aquarium, and yes they fall in love as well. The couples swap pairings and then swap back, and the film focuses on the ugliest parts of relationships, the angry, nasty, hateful and bitter breakups. This isn't Mike Nichols' best work, but that's not really a negative because his resume includes some of the greatest films of all time. There are only four characters in the movie, and Nichols does a wonderful job of letting us really get close and get to know these people. Patrick Marber's dialogue is frank and honest and leaves very little to the imagination. The performances of the actors is what sets this film apart. Especially those of Owen and Portman. Whether Owen is being hurt or he is the one inflicting the emotional pain, he is incredibly in the moment and honest. I haven't seen a better acting performance in anything in the past 10 years. And this is Portman's first real adult role, before she has always played the child trying to make her way in a world of adults, but in this film her innocence is gone, and she possesses all unenviable traits of a beautiful woman that can rip your heart out with one look. The two scenes between Owen and Portman are two of the best in the film. The best is probably Owen's performance in the "breakup scene" with he and Julia Roberts. Throughout the life of the scene Owen transforms from pure heart-broken meekness to rage, without missing a beat. Owen should win every award for acting that exists for his performance. Next to the performances, the best thing about the movie is singer/song writer Damien Rice, whose song "The Blower's Daughter" bookends the film and transports the audience into a world that initially seems to be a fantasy, but ends up more like a nightmare. I give the "Closer" a 9/10, mostly because of the brilliant acting and the films brutal honesty.

title: Take a closer look
review:
The film was done well. I wouldn't say the film was a masterpiece but it was really well done. Nichols made a really good effort just like what he did in Angels in America. Tha acting was virtually flawless. I can't imagine other actors to form an ensemble for this movie because portman,roberts, law and owen just have that perfect chemistry on portraying the "swingers" in this film.

Roberts' acting was rather dull yet wonderful. When I saw her on the film, i was expecting her to blew me away by shouting a dialog or something that will just basically push you out of your seat. But instead, her silent depressed like lines was just perfect.

Portman just blew me away. She is making a great transition from teen actress into an adult actress. Her acting was terrific and not any scene she was in that I think she have done bad at all.

Law was alright, although i've seen him done better. In my opinion, his character was the weakest of all of them because he doesn't belong to any characteristic group. Is he the sensitive guy? The foul mouthed pervert? Or is he the tough man that would kick ass?

Owen is making a name because I thought he just carried the whole film. His acting and the character he played, revealed the sick and twisted world of love. He just basically showed the whole world that he's the "expert" in this film because he's been acting his character in the Broadway for many months.

For the script, it was well written and well noted with consideration of different language difference here in England. Every line seems to be a memorable quote of this film.

I can definitely see this film winning acting awards and maybe motion picture awards. All in all, this film was beautifully done because of its "in your face" attitude about love. It exposes the reality of love in our world and not the "hollywood" love in some films. It is one of a kind because it doesn't make people imagine about love, it makes them think how love really is and just literally slapping them to wake up because this is what love is like! The film truly invites you to take a closer look on the real big picture about love and life.

title: excellent but only if you can get past the cynicism
review: I thought the characters of this movie were more fleshed out than any I've seen in a long time, even if they are all despicable and heartless. A lot of people have said that the film was terrible because it was so crass, but I love that it examines how messed up and non-chalant people can be. People just don't like what makes them uncomfortable. Also, if you have never been in the kind of relationship portrayed in the movie (or one even remotely close) it might be somewhat boring, or unbelievable that people really do such things. The acting is somewhat detached but completely compelling, especially since each actor is able to make you simultaneously sorry for them and sick of them. Your alliances switch constantly and the end is quite surprising.

title: The Apocalypse Now of relationships
review: Closer is not a portrayal of normal relationships (I hope). It shows how love can be messed up in the same way that Apocalypse now showed how war can be messed up. The characters don't seem realistic, but they can be entertaining at times. They are self-centered and do not appear to be capable of building happy, loving relationships with others. All four are prone to destructive behaviors that hurt those around them. Some other people have said it is a terrible film because of this lack of authenticity; but I disagree with this assessment. I think that it was well done but I personally didn't like it because the characters don't appear to learn to trust and love others. I would not recommend you see this film unless you just want to see something that makes you feel like the world is an awful place.

title: NC17 - XXX ACTION + LOVESQAURE +
review:
Closer is completely depressing, but it isn't a bad movie. Closer makes you feel empty, but it isn't a bad movie. It made me sad in the sense where I want to die rather than cry. Don't see the movie because Julia Roberts is in it, see it despite the fact that she's in it (although she isn't bad... just okay, which in a way is worse than being bad). Like everyone has said, Portman and Owen leave the impressions while Roberts and Law are somewhat tepid (THANK YOU 10th GRADE VOCAB WORD).

And while we're on the subject of the four starring actors, why is it that all the previews I've seen for this movie have shown mainly Jude Law and Julia Roberts? In my opinion this will attract the wrong kind of audience. Julia Roberts could be worse... at least she isn't smiling all the time like in her other movies. Now THAT would be depressing. Hide them teeth yo.

It's a harsh, truthful-although-unrealistic story based on the love-square of four subjectively sympathetic characters.

Highlight: Cyber sex scene. Ohhhhh yeah.

The language didn't affect me whatsoever. In fact, I didn't even realize there was "strong language" until I heard Oprah comment on it (not that I watch Oprah...) and read the reviews. And for the record, I'm still in high school (take that for what it's worth). I honestly think you have to be a 30 year old virgin/ proud parent of 3/ Dr. Laura enthusiast/ I don't even know/ to be offended by the language. I'm surprised people aren't more jaded by now. Wait, no I'm not.

Closer shows what sex does to a relationship without showing sex. It talks about it, revolves around it, but no, you don't see any action. If you want porn, check google images. It's free.

You do, however, get to see the behind of Natalie Portman so go if you're into that kind of thing.

Oh, and whatever critic it was a "love story for adults" is a complete twat. It's a love story about adults that are still in many ways children. It's a love story intended to show what love shouldn't be, or what love isn't.

I honestly don't even know what else to say about it. It's intriguing, see it, it's something to talk about.

title: Complex, Compelling, Closer's Classic *spoiler*
review:
Well this is the best movie I have seen since 21 Grams. I am in awe of how simple the movie is (in terms of dialogue, screen work, etc) yet how complex the characters are. The chemistry between the 4 of them is just flawless. This movie would have really been a sad affair if the acting was not at the level it was. It was refreshing to see Julia Roberts again on screen, and re-affirming her role (arguably) as Hollywood's TOP Actress. Although, Portman, based on the Alice Character, definitely has something to say about that. Those 2 definitely deserve the gold-men, come early next year.

I have a question, when exactly did Alice and Dan exchange names? That's the only part I'm left puzzled by, because I seem to remember them exchanging names before going into the cemetery, in which case, How would Jane have taken-up the name Alice Ayres?

title: Insipid, Nasty, Self Centered and, oh yes, no sex.
review: Well, I wish I could say that this movie was at least enlightening as to the sexual machinations of very attractive 30 somethings. They spend the entire movie torturing each other over sex, giving us body blow descriptions of their actions. Clive Owens plays such a nasty caveman, I half expected him to pull out his club and drag the women back to his cave. And the others were so insipid as to make Owens almost endearing. Now, had the producers had the courage to show us visually what they felt was worthy of 90 minutes of discussion, I might have bought it halfway. But without the visuals it felt like so many children throwing sand in each other's faces and not one of them willing to just get up and step out of the box.

title: complicated take on a simple sexual infatuation...
review:
I expected far more intrigue and underlying emotional roller-coaster pertaining to these four characters involved in the plot...alas, I soon discovered that it's about the usual self-doubt and desire to look for better partners, the grass is always greener on the neighbor's side...

Clive Owen's character was the only one I felt genuine sympathy for, he was the only one who could communicate his feelings totally in the movie...his pain and passion were equally portrayed, and the rest of the characters were bland compared to his. Natalie Portman's "Alice" was the sweet, lost, and in the same way old soul which I loved to watch. But Julia Roberts was her usual self and Jude Law was divine...physically speaking, of course...

All in all, I expected a better movie, but I enjoyed it nevertheless.

title: pleasantly surprised
review:
i went into the theater with a few of my girlfriends thinking this film would be some kind of romantic drama. the previews definitely keep you in the dark. my biggest fear was that it would turn out to be soft-porn for lonely housewives - a romance novel slapped onto the bigscreen. fortunately, it was neither and i was pleasantly surprised at how interesting and provocative it was. man was it painful to watch. it made me feel uncomfortable like i had unintentionally eavesdropped on someone else's argument and got caught. i enjoyed it immensely. it's a nice change from your typically formulaic Christmas/holiday fare.

i do remember some young lady saying, "that's the worst julia robert's film i've ever seen" while we were exiting the theater. what a moron. obviously she hasn't seen runaway bride, American sweethearts, and a number of other mediocre-at-best catastrophes that pock ms. robert's work history.

title: Intriguing drama
review: This movie was captivating. It is definitely different and one of my favorites. The characters are all unlikable but still keep you on the edge of your seat. It is almost like watching a play the way it jumps around. But that makes this movie different from all the other boring "same-olds" out there. The language is intense and, to agree with the previous commentator, I would not go see this with either my parents or children. However it does shock the viewer. I also love the way the movie begins and ends similarly. There is humor, drama, love, mystery, and blunt sexuality in this movie. Add Jude Law and it's on my top ten list! Also can't wait to get the soundtrack.

title: Closer still won't bring you closer
review: I really wanted to go into this movie with the best possible outlook,but I saw the bad reviews. They were right,but here goes mine. I really liked the cast of this movie,but the time gaps were terrible. They would just skip entire years and then continue the movie. There were just too many relationships here. The people were just cold without any remorse I felt. I though Clive Owen was the best character followed by Portman. I just felt that the characters lacked souls. It was really hard to watch them crumble. Several people got up and left. They were mostly older folks. Oh well, they didn't really miss much, it was really about people who liked screwing other people. IMHO

title: a good primer on why telling the truth is not a sign of maturity.
review:
The more this movie progressed the less I liked it and the characters that inhabit it. Well.. except for Natalie Portman, who's still adorable as a self loathing waif. The language gets to be quite brutal and crude, and is reminiscent of Nichols' earlier grittier 'Carnal Knowledge'. This is the way writers want people to talk when they're more concerned with being genuine than with being evolved.

Clive Owen puts a big dent in his 'new heart throb' rating with a really vicious turn as a sleazy Doctor whose only emotional range seems to be egotistic rage vented on anyone who he can't control or who bests him. His lines are the most profane in the movie, mixing every common sexual expletive with his vitriol. But he thinks he's being wonderfully genuine!

Julia Roberts plays a co-dependent who goes with whichever of the male leads who wants her the most at the time. She's playing against her star quality and she does fine in this ratcheted down persona. Jude Law on the other hand struggles as a feckless loser who feels secure with Natalie's one down role but is over his head with the stronger Julia.

The movie has many problems. The lines work better on stage, and the characters would be better played by actors not movie stars - again I would exclude darling Natalie who is still enjoying quirky character roles. The dialogue is clever but as it comes from the mouths of shallow people trying to tell the truth it just comes out as self evident dialogue. Finally it fails because uninteresting hollow people just aren't interestingÂ…except for sweet little Natalie, of course.

title: Worst film in Christendom
review:
After viewing this film of complete decadence and filth, I know for a fact that London must be high up on the Al-Qaeda nuke list. This film is the story of four grotesque, utterly selfish and vindictive monster yuppies who subsequently sleep with each other, betray each other, and scream at each other. At the end of the film I was hoping one of this big red London buses would run them all over, splattering their bodies on some dank street in Soho, anything just to shut them up from their incessant bitching and moaning. If the point of the film was to showcase the empty unfulfilled and useless lives of yuppies in America and Britain, the film succeeded wonderfully. If it wasn't, then the film is on the level of a colonoscopy in terms of raw pain. The writer of the film is a nobody, and god willing, will stay that way for a long time afterwards. One small redeeming factor about this film is that if you are dating a pretentious stuck up girl, guys you know who I mean, definitely take her to this flick. Pretend you like it, and you'll be rewarded that night. Pseudo intellectuals of all stripes will wonder at the "deepness" of the film, especially women, not realizing that the entire world could give a hoot about the love troubles of four stuck up, high income earning pricks, while there are wars across the globe, famine, and unhappiness throughout human society.

I see a film like this as an indication of how decadent and disgusting mankind in the "west" has become. Does it qualify as intellectual to write about yourself non-stop, and the relationships you've had? I'd like to think that the relationships in your life are NOT the most important thing you will do with yourself, rather, what you've done to the community around you, what you've committed to the betterment of the world would be more important. I bet at the end of the Roman Empire there were similar books and plays written, about adventures in relationships at the Vomitorium, or something else similarly arrogant. This film succeeds in producing four main characters who I was praying would be killed by the credits, begging that at least one of them would be torn asunder. I was not rewarded. Obnoxious, arrogant types will no doubt be drawn to the "complexity" of the characters. Normal people should use this film as a barometer of how repulsive a person is, by their enjoyment of it.

Avoid this tale of pure decadence and selfishness. Its popularity will be a measure of how close we are to the end of civilization.

title: love, sex, fight, swear, strip....
review:
I'm sure this film is gonna win the Oscar for best screenplay. Why? Cause every other word of dialogue is "fawk this" or " fawk that". Academy voters admire profanity in films. Proof? Other films that won the writing Oscar, like Pulp Fiction and Good Will Hunting, had 70%profane dialogue .

The plot?? Four pretentious people meet each other by accident, interact, fight, fall in love, fall out of love, cry like babies, fight some

more, and disply urbane wit by cussing each other out. All the while classical music, mawkish guitar, and New Wave music plays on the soundtrack.

However, worth the price of admission alone, is Natalie Portman's stunning scene with Clive in the strip club. Whoever was running the camera, deserves major cinematography kudos for showcasing Natalie's gorgeous body. she is so hot. Her body is a 10. Alas, the film is not. Thanks for reading. Bye.

title: Pointless and dull
review: Must be a female movie. I watched to the end, but it made no sense and if this crap happens in real life it would seem a sorry situation. Who cares about fools that do this in their personal lives.

title: One lime
review: A simple deconstruction of love in the modern world, especially on how masculinity tears relationships apart.

title: Worst movie !!!!!!!!
review:
The movie starts good but later the story sucks.

"Closer" isn't the kind of film just any audience would enjoy. The film features complex sexual and relationship themes that might leave some viewers cold. A hollow and disappointing offering from Director. Dialogue is mediocre and contrived. Not grounded in reality.This film explores the sexual politics of a metro-sexual elite, it is not a genuine universal exploration of love and the damage it does.

The movie shows that the world has life with only betrayal and selfishness and not the true love...

In short The movie is 'Awful" I give 1/10 for the movie...........

title: A dreary tale set in a dreary City and a waste of a fine cast
review:
This is just not the kind of movie I enjoy so my review is bound to be downgrading. My initial and final reaction, after sitting through the whole dreary thing in the comfort of my own den (had I seen it in a cinema theatre I would have left long before the end), is why on earth were such a set of four fine actors persuaded to perform in such a pointless exercise? I've given Closer two stars mainly for the heroic efforts the actors must have had to make in dealing with a banal script and uninteresting parts. The whole thing seems to be about three disillusioned aging yuppies and one barely past-puberty attractive young waitress-stripper (23 year old Natalie Portman who plays Alice aka as Janet Rachel Jones). The play seeks to explore the sexual and personal relationships between four people who have met by chance in the City. That storyline might have been interesting except the characters are so selfishly wrapped up in themselves they are more even boring than some deadly boring real life self-absorbed couples I have actually met. Who would want to know about such people when there is so little of interest to learn? A psychiatrist, just back from a refreshing Caribbean holiday, might be prepared to hear their individual stories (and be well paid for doing so) but I am glad it only cost me fifty cents as the DVD came for that extra with the Sunday newspaper. I am not glad, however, that it cost me just about 90 minutes of my life to watch. The absurd thing is while in the modern fashion they are into partner swapping the two males get extremely uptight when they discover that their former bed mate is sleeping with the other guy. They constantly demand the truth from each partner and then don't like it when it's fed to them chapter and verse. Towards the end of the movie I recalled the 1957 film, The Little Hut, except that was a love triangle, not a quartet and also a movie I would like to forget but at least its script contained an element of humour, These things work much better as comical farces than as a drama which one is supposed to take seriously. In fact I usually prefer Julia Roberts in comedies or least melodramas. She is simply is not right for straight parts.

I cannot understand one professional critic who is quoted on the back of the DVD cover writing of Closer "it vibrates with eroticism, bruising laughs and dynamic performance". In my opinion exactly the three elements that are almost entirely lacking in the movie.

Despite the actors' best efforts their performance was hardly dynamic. The script and story didn't allow it any more than would have one for a Cinderella pantomime. As to vibrating with eroticism I would say this movie is no more erotic than a Made in China plastic vibrator urgently needing a battery replacement. Except possibly the one scene in the back room of strip club where Natalie Portman displays much of her pretty young body. But then if some voyeur wanted a good erotic pornography movie there is plenty of such dedicated stuff around without the need to view this particular DVD. In my eyes Julia Roberts was never very beautiful and a personality quite lacking in eroticism. As a young actress she was quite pretty and funny as a prostitute with Richard Gere and still vaguely attractive in a comic way as a film star who falls in love with a stuttering Hugh Grant, but she is rapidly losing her beauty and sex appeal as she ages and evident in this 2004 work. Richard Owen is ruggedly handsome but his role requires him to make remarks to Julia Roberts which suggests the character he portrays is not very sure of himself as regards his sexual performance, more of having a medical problem than erotic in nature. I was also disappointed with Jude Law who I first saw and admired in his secondary role in Gatacca. In Closer he looks seedy, effeminate and unkept. As to "laughs" the only lines that induced a slight giggle on my part was when Judes's character is asked if he still writes obituaries for a newspaper. His reply is "No more, I've been promoted as obituary page editor" When asked "how come? he replies "The previous editor died"! No exactly hilarious and probably not original. The whole play is set in a grey London winter, mostly in probably expensive but darkened flats and lofts which just adds to the overall impression of the banal dreariness that overwhelms the film. May be that's what the producer set out to achieve. It seems the movie won two Golden Globes and two Academy Award nominations (for Owen and Portman's performance in both cases).

I'm sorry , there are plenty of folk who seem to love this film but what I have written is my view after "giving it a go".

title: "Closer" starring Names as FURNITURE!
review:
This is definitely Number One on my list of the Worst Movies Ever Made.

Movies like "Showgirls", "The Cell", "Signs", "Mullholland Drive", "Million Dollar Hotel", "Gosford Park", "Star Wars Episode 1: The Phantom Menace", "Wired", "Great Balls of Fire" come after this for one reason and one reason only:

THIS MOVIE RUINED MY ENTIRE WEEKEND! THERE WAS NOTHING I COULD ENJOY AFTERWARD BECAUSE I WAS TOO PREOCCUPIED WITH THE FACT THAT THIS FILM OF THE WORST EXCUSES FOR CHARACTERS WAS EVER MADE AND I ACTUALLY WATCHED IT!!!!!!!

If I didn't know any better, I'd try to find some legal technicality from which I could sue and collect a monetary settlement from everyone involved with the writing, green-lighting, financing, casting, acting, shooting, catering, cutting, producing, editing, printing, copying, and advertising of this showcase of pathetic excuse for a movie, but, like I said, I know better.

Natalie Portman, who hasn't had a good role since "Leon/The Professional", is miscast as a no-nonsense, fast talking stripper, which is like casting Spike Lee to play a Grand Wizard of the KKK. Julia Roberts plays a photographer. That's all you need to know. Jude Law plays a guy who's as pathetic as almost ANY character played by Julian Sands. Even worse: he SOUNDS LIKE HIM!! Clive Owen plays a doctor who can't deliver a line (even when it's supposed to be shocking, due to foul language) any better than the Domino's Pizza guy can deliver a pizza to Bangladesh in 30 minutes or less.

The movie is completely, utterly, mind-numbingly boring and you would just as well watch a movie about the house you grew up in (if you took yourself and your family out of the picture) and cast Julia Roberts, Clive Owen, Natalie Portman and Jude Law as The Front Door, The Oven, The Living Room Table, and A Spatula.

Aaaannnnd .... CUT! That's a wrap.

title: My summary of Closer
review: I especially liked the song "Can't take my eyes off of you" and Julia Roberts, as always, acts superbly. But, is it me, or do most English actors sound wooden and untrue? The storyline was average but I just couldn't believe the acting ability of Jude Law and Clive Owen. They seem more ideally suited to average English stage productions than to big film acting. Natalie Portman played a great role. The Opera House was filmed beautifully and the various streets and sights of London were also appealing to someone who has never seen or visited London. Did I mention that Julia Roberts, as she always does, acts wonderfully and I thought that anything with her in it would have had me hanging off my seat but, terribly sorry, this film, was not well acted and I want my money back.

title: A resounding success on all fronts
review:
Based on a stage play by Patrick Marber, Closer tells the story of four people living in the upper crust of London society. All of these characters are flawed to an extent that it is the flaws themselves that make up their personalities, and that makes it very hard to really care for any of them. This is made up, however, by the scene setting. Patrick Marber also wrote the screenplay for this film, and some of his scenes are just brilliant. They're always interesting because of the things that the characters do and say to each other - their motives are well worked out, and even though you don't really like any of them; it's still possible to get behind them because their characters are so well defined and seeing them reveal themselves on screen is always great to watch. The film doesn't really have a plot to speak of, and all the action comes about through the characters themselves rather than any actual plotting. This may be a bad thing for some people, because the film lacks structure - but I liked the way that it panned out because it also makes it unpredictable and, as the characters are the stars anyway, it also ensures that we see them for what they are, as they don't have to follow any plot line.

For the characters, Mike Nichols has recruited four big names. Natalie Portman stands out the most among the cast members. This beautiful and talented young actress makes every scene she's in a treat for the eyes, and her beauty does Closer no end of favours in that respect. She has the best scene in the movie, which is shared by Clive Owen and takes place in a strip club! It's been years since Julia Roberts made anything worth seeing, and for that reason; she's the sore thumb of this cast of up and coming young stars. The male leads give strong performances, and Clive Owen in particular stands out. He's a very strong actor and that translates well to his character. Similarly, Jude Law's screen presence suits his character excellently but in a different way. Mike Nichols has his first big success with an adaptation of a stage play with the brilliant "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?", and although this film doesn't come close to the brilliance of that one, the great director has managed to inject just the right tone into the proceedings and it is that which ultimately makes Closer the success that it is.

title: Don't rent the DVD --- and if you do, turn it off after the first 20 minutes
review:
The only redeeming quality this movie had was its actors.

Unfortunately, the actors couldn't make up for the film's many flaws: entirely too slow, too disjointed, too strange, and pointless.

I found the first 15-30 minutes or so entertaining, but after that the film was a waste. Sometime around the 20 or 30 minute mark I kept thinking to myself "I should turn off this DVD and walk away", but I made the mistaking of then saying to myself "No, it has to get better soon"--- Too bad I said that; because the rest of the movie was a waste of time. My recommendation to you: If this is a movie that starts to bore you after the first 20-30 minutes, don't expect any change in pace........just shut the movie off and go do something more enjoyable with your evening. :)

title: Interesting but not what it seems.
review:
Just saw this movie with a friend. It's mostly about mind and sex, and how both of these screw up relationships.

I really miss one thing throughout the whole movie: what about love?

From an intelligent point of view, people will like this. Fast dialog's, clever plot, some funny words here and there, etc... But I really do miss the most important aspect here which is LOVE itself. It is totally missing in the story. But hey, maybe that's the clue?!

And after you saw this movie, don't think about it too much. You might get into trouble yourself! It's interesting, but not what it seems.

So... unfortunately I would not recommend seeing this.

title: A Trenchant Analysis of Tony Blair's Britain - Yeah, Right
review: Other reviewers here have given good evidence as to why this film is a failure, so I need not go on about it here. I would like to add however, that 'Closer' does show, without any sort of brilliance or depth, just what a bland bore Tony Blair's 'Cool Britannia' has become. Where boring people are content with being snotty and obnoxious and self-centered, and there's really no outstanding reason NOT to be. The emptiness is everywhere. And what are two American women doing in all of this? The story might as well be in Dacron, Ohio. London is as nothing. And Mike Nichols! Once a master director, now, his talents ebbing, attempting to make a hip picture with hipper stars, should have known better. This rubbish, from the man who brought you 'Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf' and 'The Graduate'! Think about retirement, Mike. Every opportunity for making this story into something noteworthy was spitefully thrown away. At least the petulantly 'victorious' so-called dermatologist Clive Owen could have tossed in a scabies or eczema joke or something when he has just reduced delicate Jude Law to tears. And this, in the Land of Monty Python! It almost makes one pine for the Thatcherite days, when at least the Great British spirit of satire was alive and well. Now we have a sort of transatlantic blandness. Yak yak yak, blah blah blah. So I have to assume that the cast and crew thought they were making some sort of intellectual statement, either via a modern existentialism, or via a much baser technique: by bludgeoning the audience softly with just plain boring and uninteresting empty characters. If they wanted to dabble in this sort of water, they could have at least done a viewing of Peter Greenaway's masterpiece, 'The Cook, The Thief, His Wife and Her Lover'. But boring is safer and does not require so much depth or imagination.

title: Depressing waste of time about cruel, unhappy people who are obsessed with each other.
review:
This is a depressing story about four petty, unhappy, cruel people who are perfectly willing to lie, cheat, manipulate, and destroy each other to satisfy their obsession with each other. The show started out sweet and romantic, but that didn't last long.

I found it very difficult to identify with any of the characters, because they seemed to develop an obsession with another person at the drop of a hat, before they even knew anything about the other person, and they seemed to fall in and out of love at a moment's notice without any real reason for it.

I kept waiting for the movie to redeem itself, but it never did. I'm surprised at how bad it is, considering the great acting talent and the positive reviews from many critics. It was a disappointing waste of time.

title: Do not waste your time on this one!
review:
After having read the gushing reviews below for "Closer", I decided to shell out some cash to buy a DVD copy of it. Luckily the outlay was not very much, as I bought it whilst on holiday in Malaysia. However, from which ever way you look at it, it is either...

A - sub standard Nic Roeg, strangers in a strange land coming together to explore their sexualities

or

B - it's a film about a stripper, where she does not actually get them off or if she does, Clive Owen's head gets in the way.

Patrick Marber should stick to writing one liners for Steve Coogan, rather than come out with this pretentious dross.

This film is not worth your money, let alone your precious time.

title: Don't worry about a plot, it does not have much of one.
review: To be frank, my friends and i are debating whether this was in fact the worst movie we have ever seen (though it is not much of a debate). We are asking anyone who was involved with this movie to please, give us our hour and a half back. There was nothing entertaining about this movie, other than a nearly nude Natalie Portman, and fellas, there is not nearly enough shown to justify spending any money to view this movie. The movie is only dialog, which is incredibly poor, and never even came close to being dramatic. Any attempt at a plot was simply shot down by a severe lack of realism, and conversations that went no where slowly. I give it a .10 out of ten, beating out League of Extraordinary Gentlemen for the coveted title of WORST MOVIE EVER!!

title: It sucked!
review:
This movie sucked! I advise no one to see this movie, it was pointless, boring, and didn't even make sense...

They never told you when timed passed, and didn't show any recognizable transition...

Never see this movie, it sucked...

Half of it didn't make sense, and their accents made it so that you couldn't understand what half of them are saying...

The ending of this movie was so terrible, it made me want to cry...

Never, I repeat, never even think of getting this movie, tell your friends, "Closer sucked", and save them and hour and a half of pure confusion and boredom...

title: Very disappointing
review:
I was eager to see this film but was very disappointed in the end as all 4 protagonists seemed unlikeable characters and pretty selfish to me.

I've previously enjoyed both Clive Owen & Jude Laws as actors. I didn't know if I'd like the female leads. Julia was OK & Nathalie was almost believable, but I don't think I'd be friends with these kinds of people.

Some things didn't add up: why did Jane lie about her name to Larry but not to Dan?

I was surprised by the looseness of their 'love' for each other. No wonder relationships go haywire! Ultimately this was a bit pretentious. Maybe the play works better.

3/10

title: Bad. Really, really bad. Awesomely bad. Monumentally bad.
review: The wife and I seldom give up on a movie. Dr. T and the Women was an exception. Without a Paddle was another, but we didn't feel so bad, as it was the back end of a double feature. Closer makes three. Maybe it's unfair for me to review it, because it only polluted our DVD player for about twenty minutes before the poor thing gagged, retched and and spat it out. I've read others who comment on the intelligent dialogue. Maybe they were listening to an SAP channel or something. Pretentious/cutesy and so achingly full of itself that it was embarrassing would be our take on it. I don't care how misogynistic you may be, there is no way you are going to convince me that even marginally intelligent, educated and/or sophisticated people talk like this or relate to each other like this. I know. I'm a people. And I would laugh myself to tears if I ever encountered a poser like any of these characters. I think the internet chat scene was the breaking point for us. Had the cast consisted of eleven year olds it may have been believable, but even then one wonders why anyone would think it worthwhile to commit such drek to film. We did hang on into the aquarium scene, hoping against hope that since the film seemed to garner a number of decent ratings perhaps the first part was just a mistake of some sort and something worth watching might actually happen. It didn't. Eject. If you're a poser yourself, maybe you'll find something of interest in this film (I'm not going to even speculate on what that might actually be). If you're an authentic human being living within several light years of the planet I inhabit, I can't think of one single reason why you should subject yourself to this mess.

title: horrible movie
review: Am I the only person who was so bored during this movie I had to force myself to stay awake, thinking maybe something exciting MIGHT happen!? This looked so much better in the previews it's almost false advertisement. Very slow moving, dull, and just plain boring. Jude Law and Julia Roberts are two great actors so I was looking forward to this movie. but Julia didn't have a huge script and Jude was the only attraction to this movie. Having two very unknown actors to replace them would just make the movie un-watchable if that is a word. Don't waste your time, unless you are very patient and don't mind slow paced boring movies with very explicit language.

title: Closer than comfortable
review:
Dialogue stripped to the bare minimum, characters struggling with truth and lies, and exploration of the inner workings of the psyche. This kind of stuff I usually leave alone, but considering the cast and director involved, I thought I'd better check it out.

I am very glad that I followed my instinct, as I find myself profoundly affected by this film. It is not a comfortable ride, but one that I found mesmeric, challenging and thought-provoking.

All the leads are convincing, with Clive Owen giving a blindingly good portrayal of an everyday psychopath (or is he just much more upfront than most of us?) Natalie Portman is also excellent, bringing the kind of spark that made Leon - The Professional such a success, except that now she's sexually mature, which makes life more interesting... On first viewing, Jude Law and Julia Roberts didn't have quite as impact as Owen and Portman, but their roles are the more introverted ones, and I look forward to assessing the depths of their portrayals in further viewings.

What really glues Closer together, though, is the editing. Like the dialogue, it is bare bones stuff, with four years of four characters lives condensed into an hour and a half. With dots of detail Nichols conjures up a vivid portrait of the relationships between the characters. But it is the twists and turns that make up the beginnings and ends of relationships that are really the subject of this movie.

Be warned: this is not light material. But rarely do you find such a taut and compelling drama containing no weapons but words, and no action but the tearing asunder of hearts and dreams.

title: A moving play, turned into an amazing movie
review:
What every ignorant person here, who walked out out or says the movie is complete horrendous crap is that this was not a movie, this was theatre on the big screen. Read the play it'll do you a lot of good, it is the exact same thing, but from what I can tell is that you probably never had and never will sit through a theatre play in your life. It was great drama, from step one and it was driven with the words and language, which is what theatre is driven by, the text not the actions.

This was probably one of the greatest transformations of theatre to the big screen, because nothing was changed, ecept for the ending, but you needen't not know what that is, but if you must buy the book and read the play.

This theatre transformation to film is amazing, I loved every second of it and I went back and say it again for the second and third time, and it was just as great, and I loved so much more of it, an learned so much more from it.

Watch it, read it do everything you can do and see it again and again.

title: Painfully Realistic
review:
This is one of the greatest films I've seen in my life, and that's probably even an understatement. Four actors have never been better, and it was a pleasure to see each of them in such a different kind of role. They've earned my admiration and respect.

The reason this movie is so powerful is because there are few people who can't relate to some romantic situation presented. We feel the happiness, pain, vulnerability, etc. the characters are going through. This film is intended for a mature audience, so if you decide this movie is for you please use wise judgement when deciding who to take. There are also strong sexual dialogues, so if you blush or feel uncomfortable when someone mentions sex, you probably will be squirming in your chair the entire time. However, if you can see past that into the depth of the characters and plot, then you'll really enjoy this.

title: This movie was so true
review: I felt like I was re-living parts of my life with this movie, I saw it a few days ago and I still can't get it out of my head. The funny thing is I wanted to go watch Blade Trinity but my wife dragged me to this instead. I'm not a big lovie type of movie fan. I did like "Say Anything" though. Closer really touched home with me. I'm not sure what else to say, I loved this movie. Everything about this movie was so real, it's actually scary. The part where Dan leaves Alice, I can't get that out of my mind, so haunting. Was like Deja Vu for me. If any of my friends ask me though, I'm going to deny it and say it's a stupid chick flick. I got a rep to keep. ;-)

title: Up close and impersonal...
review:
CLOSER has the makings of your typical romantic comedy: A contrived change-partners-and-romance plot; love-at-first-sight meet-cute situations; glamorously superficial characters played by superficially glamorous actors; manipulative schemes to seduce and/or abandon lovers; and glib, archly self-satisfied dialogue. The film offers up nothing that hasn't been done hundreds, if not thousands, of times in hundreds, if not thousands, of movies and sitcoms. Indeed, it has everything you would want in a romantic comedy, except for two things: romance and comedy.

Dark and brooding, CLOSER is one of those insufferably smug exercises in droning pomposity that truly thinks it is delivering a pious sermon of Truth and Honesty about Relationships -- though the word used in the movie isn't "relationships," but a less polite one that begins with the letter "f." The use of profanity -- the f-word being just one of many bandied about in the film with casual contempt -- is meant to punctuate just how Truthful and Honest the characters/filmmakers are. It is also an indication of just how lazy and/or pretentious the writer is.

The basic storyline is trite, but admittedly dependable: She (Natalie Portman) loves he (Jude Law), who falls in love with her (Julia Roberts), who is attracted to him (Clive Owen) -- though everybody plays musical beds -- until, in the best of all possible soap operas fashion, everybody ends up (or doesn't end up) with the right person. But in CLOSER, who ends up with who is irrelevant, since the characters are so truly petty, self-centered and deceitful, it is impossible to care if any of them live happily ever after. Maybe that is screenwriters Patrick Marber's point: Lovers and liars are synonymous words -- unselfish love is a contradiction of terms. Such cynicism is nothing new in movies like this, but usually it is eased down with a bittersweet coat of humanity, if not humor. Marber revels in the bitter, but denies the sweet: The characters have to keep telling us just how madly in love they are with each other since the film supplies them with precious little screen time to actually show it. Any display of love, kindness or even respect between any given couple is merely a preamble to an act of betrayal or rejection or revenge.

While enduring the movie, one can amuse oneself trying to figure out the point of the title, which seems to be a misnomer since no character really ever gets particularly close to another before they begin to push each other away. I assume the title refers to the way that the story condenses time into bite-sized pieces, revealing the film's roots as a multi-act play. Since the story takes place over a period of four or five years, the characters keep having to announce that a year has past between scenes to explain gaps in the story's logic. And repeatedly segments of the film begin with characters announcing their undying passion and ending with them angrily breaking up, squeezing days or weeks of reality into a few minutes of unconvincing, heightened melodrama. Such artificial manipulation of time is understandable in a play, but unnecessary and irritating in a film which pretends to take place in the real world. It is possible that director Mike Nichols was purposely trying to mislead the audience about the timing of events in order to make a point, but what that point might be is unclear.

To give them credit, the actors do what they can with so little to work with. Their characters are one-dimensional at best and clichÃ©d at worst. (Marber's idea of originality is making Portman's waif-like character a stripper, rather than a prostitute. Wow, how daring!) At least Roberts endows her character with a consistent tone, albeit one of somber self-absorption; I guess there is a certain triumph for her in being able to suppress under a cloud of chilly aloofness all that warm charisma that has made her a star. Meanwhile, Portman, Law and Owen have to somehow make their characters sudden shifts in attitude and temperament credible, with varying degrees of success. All are at the mercy of Marber's empty, loveless pessimism.

Mike Nichols is one heck of a director and he has a quartet of perfectly capable actors at his command for this film. And he has trod this path before with films like WHO'S AFRAID OF VIRGINIA WOOLF? (a great movie) and CARNAL KNOWLEDGE (an overrated movie), so he has experience in turning theatrical artifice into credible cinema. But those films had complex stories and even more complex characters (and arguably, much better actors). Here all Nichols has is Marber's adaptation of his own "award-winning play," which presumably has lost something in the translation. As a result, the closer you look, the less there is to see.

title: Love it seems, is no more than a fancy lie.
review:
Please visit my website www.worldofkj.com and check out the forums!

Closer

By: Karl Schneider

Love it seems, is no more than a fancy lie.

Any movie with a cast like the one brought together in Closer immediately jumps out at you, grabs you, and makes you want to rush out and see it. Couple this with a very intriguing trailer, and you have a movie that gets thoughts of possible Oscar Nominations rumbling about in your head. Add that to the promise of Natalie Portman as a stripper, which is enough for me by its lonesome, and you best believe I am going. Speaking of Portman, has she evolved beautifully as an actress or am I hallucinating again? I won't lie, I have always adored the girl, but I had never realized she was so amazingly talented. First seeing her in The Professional as a cute girl with a plant befriending a hit man after her parents murder, I should have seen her potential. Regardless I missed it, and failed to pickup on her blooming career. I was unimpressed by her in Star Wars, mainly because of her co-star who we will forever refer to as 'Anchor' because of his uncanny ability to ruin an amazing movie, and I tended to glance over her other performances with this yawning gaze. Recently though this young girl from Jerusalem has really come into her own, first with Garden State, and now with Closer where she manages to overshadow one of the greatest female actresses of our time. Just stunning.

Closer as a movie works very well. It is entertaining, funny, dramatic, and most importantly has a realistically believable story allowing its all star cast to really run with their roles. Between Jude Law, Clive Owen, Natalie Portman, and Julia Roberts their isn't a single average performance. Everyone of them becomes their role, developing it to the fullest extent and making them real people with their own unique intricacies, facing their own problems. Only one character comes off as remotely likable, something that oddly enough doesn't prevent you from becoming attached to the drama that ensues. You are still so drawn to the various characters that you can't help but watch the train wreck their lives become.

The only real failing of Closer is its ungodly want to jump around through time with no indication of where it is going, leaving those viewing to play catch up. It is nothing serious, and quite easy to pick up upon, but at the same time I can't help wondering why they purposefully lacked any transition when skipping through things as large as a whole year of the characters lives.

Other than the jet lag you get upon stepping out of Closer's time machine, the movie is outstanding. It takes something so highly regarded like love, and drags it down into the mud, finally letting it up only after it has totally filled it with lies and deceit. As depressing as it can be at times to see Closer tear apart something as virtuous as love, it really does nothing but make it all the more stronger. To borrow a bit, there is always that moment, that one instant where you can stop, turn back and choose not to do something. Being able to do that is what makes love truly special, and what makes it sad to watch these characters fall apart as they do.. Even with it's depressingly uplifting tone, Closer manages, in it's own little way, to strengthen the bonds of love you have with others, though after this you may find yourself watching just a little bit ... closer.

Grade: B+

title: Closer To Perfection Each Time I See It
review:
[WARNING: This review contains some language and a whole lot of senseless

blathering about how fantastic Mike Nichols is]

All right, Nichols, you win.

I've been looking, I guess, for a favorite director for some time now. It was jumbled between Polanski, Fuller, Allen, and even Takashi Miike for awhile, but they all wane (slightly, mind you, but still wane) in awe at Mike Nichols.

I was wondering how this movie, being a relationship movie, would stack up

with audiences, to quote the film, to "that witch we do not speak of."* To be honest, it was about as divided, but I think it's a clear sign that since most of the people who came out of Closer who either liked it or hated it spoke with such vocabulary and a surprising, staunch lack of grammar. True quote: "Fantastic

movie... must... defenestrate... DVD collection." People literally are entranced by this piece of pure, unmitigated CINEMA, damn it!

The story is sparse. It is more about the feelings of the characters than the actual plot, but here's my take: couples cheating on one another. That's pretty much all you need to know plotwise. The plot does not fail in any way. In fact, the

minimalism is key to the reflection in the mirrors that are the script and acting. WHOOOOLY HECK. The dialogue as stilted as hell, and guess what? It works,

like a charm. It feels very much like the play it was scripted on, and that just gets me thinking: relationships really are like a play going on before you, and that's why people say things as trite as "do you think I'm ugly?" or "please, don't leave me." In any other movie (like the one by the asterisk at the end), this dialogue would have faltered, but the pure frankness of the events that unfold and the way that they are portrayed is genius. Julia Roberts, who I really don't like, gives her best performance, bar none, and she's incredibly convincing. In one

particular scene, she and Clive Owen are both as frank, biting, and funny as the movie they star in. Jude Law's truly shone this year in his pictures, and he

shines the brightest here (yep, even better than in Huckabees, and he was

pretty damn good in that one). Natalie Portman, though not nude, is probably

the best of the foursome. Admittedly, she has the best lines of dialogue, but only she could make them as funny and as tragic as they are.

The best thing about Closer? No matter how straightforward it is with breakups and infidelity, it never loses its sense of surreality, which is tough to pull off if your name doesn't start with an "R" and end with an "oman Polanski." The way

the film is shot is perfect: any scene that involves infidelity or a question of infidelity, the camera angles become obscure (not too obscure) so that the

unfortunate events playing out on screen become that much more effective.

So in all, how is it? Three words: "Life On Screen" or "Pure F'n Cinema."

Yep, it's that good. :)

*The movie referred to was indeed Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind. And

unless you don't have a funny bone and are not in relationship, Closer dunks

Eternal Sunshine's head in the toilet bowl 98 times, one for each minute of film.

YES: IT'S THAT GOOD. :D

title: Don't bother getting "Closer"
review:
I saw closer on Monday. I wanted to like this movie, unfortunately I found it contrived, hard to follow, and while it has good performances and is fundamentally well acted, the characters are totally unbelievable and the dialog is ridiculous. I wanted to like this movie for many different reasons, the cast, the director, the chance to see Natalie Portman playing a stripper, but even that couldn't save this movie. This movie had to be better in its original form as a play because it's not a very good movie.

'Closer' tells the story of four strangers and their relationships. Dan and Alice (Jude Law and Natalie Portman) and Larry and Anna (Julia Roberts and Clive Owen). It begins with their instant attractions that turn into relationships, and then onto betrayal and infidelity, and back again. Set in modern day London, 'Closer' is the tale of love, love lost, honesty and relationships.

Part of the problem with this movie comes from the fact that it was originally performed on stage as a play, which was then adapted by the original playwright into the screenplay. The movie feels like it should be on a stage not on a movie screen. It has very static locations, long-winded dialog that no one who is not on stage would ever say, and a general 'this should be on Broadway feel to it. However this is not what dooms this movie, it's the unrealistic character interaction, it's the unexplained jumps through months and years of time, and it's the constant barrage of unbelievable dialog.

The movie credits itself with being an honest look at relationships, infidelity, and love but after watching this film you will ask yourself 'Why are all these people so stupid?' Everyone is cheating on everyone else and everyone loves someone else, or then again maybe they don't. All we know is that the characters are so enraptured with love one moment and then literally two minutes later they are not in love anymore, and then you guessed it, a couple minutes later they are in love again, or maybe not. One thing is for sure though they love to talk about their pain, and what better why then with long in-depth, well thought out monologues. All of the characters have really graphic conversations about sex and cheating that sound well rehearsed and thoroughly contrived.

'Closer' definitely has a few enjoyable moments or good laughs but they are few and far between. You will find yourself getting angry at the characters and the unexplained jumps in time between scenes. While the movie conveys some of the true hardships of love, the situations the characters are put in and their reactions could only happen in the movies. Unless you really want to see Natalie Portman almost naked save 'Closer' for cable.

title: A film like this should never have been made
review: First of all, what was the purpose of making this film. It did not entertain nor was it meaningful in any way. I am what is considered elderly, but I don't expect every movie to be Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs. Language used in context with the movie is alright. But the content of this went way beyond language and sex. It was, to be direct, disgusting. Worst of all, it has greatly lowered my admiration of Julia Roberts. With all of the good movies she has made, why did she lower herself to be involved in this crap. With all the wonderful story lines out there, this was not a movie I would recommend to anyone. Someday her children will watch their mother's performances. Will they be proud of her after this movie.

title: Insight into the mindset of a dirty old man
review: So Mike Nichols has morphed into a dirty old man making inane dirty movies. What a disappointment. I knew nothing about this flick going in except that I mostly like Julia Roberts and Clive Owens. But really! I have heard the C word used in real life once, and I have been around the block a few times. Am I really supposed to believe that upper-middle-class people in modern-day London use it in every other sentence? (Or so it seemed. Gratuitous and shocking to me, and I am no prude.) Who do the writers and Nichols (and presumably Nichols' wife Diane Sawyer) hang around with? Oh, that's right, pretentious artsy fartsy types who may or may not be gay. Give me a break. No more Mike Nichols flicks for me. I am up to here with dirty old men, e.g., Nichols and Hugh Hefner. Ewww!

title: Not for everyone's taste, but a superb tour de force for those can digest serious theatre
review:
Closer is a deceptively innocuous film about four young singletons in contemporary London that has divided critics fiercely.

Set casually and unpretentiously across such fabulous locations as the South Bank, the London Aquarium, the National Portrait Gallery and the Theatre Royal, this intelligent, biting and (at times) shocking film will thrill as much as it will appal.

I liked the four virtuoso performances, tightly scripted action, psychological dilemmas of sexual politics set against a modern lifestyle, constant surprises, and the soul searching it offers on the importance of truth in relationships, the meaning of love and the things that are needed to make a relationship work (or ensure it will flounder).

It's director Mike Nichols most powerful tour-de-force since the classic Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf, easily surpassing the more commercial fare of Graduate or Working Girl, the minor anti-nuclear film Silkwood, or the flawed and over-ambitious Catch 22. It's a film that works on many levels and matures from repeated viewing.

The four lead characters are newspaper (obituary) writer played by Jude Law, Natalie Portman as a new woman who comes into his life, commercial photographer admirably understated by Julia Roberts, and finally Clive Owen as a dermatologist. The actual action is incidental. The main point is the way they interact and form relationships.

Closer has been adapted for screen by award winning playwright Patrick Marber from his stage play of the same name. This may give a clue as to the nature of the film - what is marketed deceptively as an almost light-hearted romp (which is what it starts out as), has an acerbic and even vitriolic core that is more suited to serious viewers than those looking for straightforward entertainment. This is also the movie's main flaw: it is not everyone's cup of tea. Additionally, there will be large groups of people who will be shocked or disappointed. There is not much graphic sex, but there are very explicit verbal battles of a sexual nature, and persons who might be offended or turned off by jealousy arguments about who put what where and what their bodily fluids tasted like might as well save themselves the price of admission.

There are, however, some excellent comic moments, such as when Dan asks Anna "Do you want babies?" and she quips back, "Yes, but not today." Similarly, the scene where Dan cons Larry in a sexually explicit internet chat room is almost unbearably funny in an excruciating sort of way. But the meat of the movie is reserved for big questions about how we view relationships and 'edit out' bits we don't like when we remember them fragmentally, or through the keyhole of our single, personalised viewpoint.

Happily married people who have never had to sail the tempestuous seas of dating and trial relationships may find it harder to identify with the characters, but many others will be able to project themselves into these intelligent, strikingly attractive and trendy would-be relationshippers. People can put their better selves forward as honestly as possible but then get mired in situations that are of their own making but not of their own ultimate choosing or living up to their own ideals, and in various ways this is what we see happen in the film. For some, the process of getting 'closer' may be painful, or the closeness may come with the realisation that it wasn't the marriage made in heaven you thought it might be.

In the opening (slow motion) scene, Jude Law and Natalie Portman move towards each other with sizzling self-confidence and oozing devastating sexuality. If they are cocky, it is in the suaveness that affects many eligible young adults, that self-effacing sureness that is designed to elicit the attention of the opposite sex in an almost accidental way. Natalie Portman shines through several remarkably different 'real selves' until the stunning denouement where we can come to know her and understand the difference between her honesty in the sense of trueness to oneself and honesty in the more literal sense.

Clive Owen, as Larry, the realistic doctor who combines intellect and a certain amount of breeding with a sometimes vicious honesty, achieves a performance that will jump start his career to greater things. Julia Roberts, sadly too often known more for her star appeal than her acting, gives probably her best performance since Erin Brockovich as a successful and self-sufficient photographer. Instead of stealing the limelight by making her character stage centre, she underplays it, giving conviction to her part rather than reminding us she is a superstar. Finally, the talented Jude Law as Dan, who aspires to be more decisive and successful than he maybe has the stamina for, captures our imagination with his all too human failings, his attempts to prove his sincerity, and his good looks.

Closer features a charismatic soundtrack starting with Damien Rice's haunting 'Blower's Daughter' and continues with frequent excerpts from Mozart's similarly themed Cosi fan Tutti. Like many things in the film, the Rice track, where he sings, "Can't take my eyes off you" has more than one meaning. For anyone unfamiliar with Mozart's opera, I can say it asks the age-old question: how much can you really trust your lover? with earth-shattering consequences for everyone concerned. In our movie, for those who are seeking some answers from what on the surface is a very cynical view of modern adult liaisons, some clues may be picked up from the throw-away comment, "You don't know the first thing about love because you don't understand compromise." Oh yes - and watch out for who finally makes it through to the end, and ask why!

I've seen Closer twice already and can't recommend it strongly enough - although I also hope my comments have put off those people who won't enjoy it and might have gone to see it in the mistaken belief that they would find it digestible.

title: Sex, Lies and a Lot of Emotional Red Tape.
review: Sensationally realized adult-themed drama that is about as subtle as a sledgehammer with its electrifying performances, magnetic direction and hard-as-nails script. In modern-day London a struggling journalist/obituary writer (Jude Law) falls in love with a young American stripper (Natalie Portman). Their relationship is thrown a curve-ball when Law meets photographer Julia Roberts. Roberts appears to not be interested and Law unwittingly gets dermatologist Clive Owen involved with her instead. Almost instantly, Roberts and Owen start a love affair of their own. However, nothing is as rosy as it appears. Law is really in lust with Roberts, Roberts is quietly obsessed with Law and Portman is coming apart at the seams emotionally as she learns about Law's true feelings. While all this occurs Owen gets caught in a pickle as well as he realizes that there is much more to Law and Roberts' relationship than meets the eye. And a short conversation between Owen and Portman may also lead to more fireworks as time goes by. Talk about lovers and other strangers. Wickedly demented chess match of wits, would-be-loves, lusts, jealousies and cruelties culminate in arguably the most brilliant and important picture of 2004. The four leads create a crazed square in a dark and bleak London landscape. Each individual performer has an earth-shattering moment and each has at least one emotional sparring match with each of the other three co-stars. Symbolism is also a key ingredient in this recipe. The occupations of the four leads being the most important of examples. Taking place briskly over a four-year period, "Closer" highlights its points with striking blows and difficult outcomes. Director Mike Nichols gets back to the wild and revolutionary film-making that shook Hollywood and the system with 1960s classics "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" and "The Graduate". Patrick Marber's screenplay, based on his equally potent play, is a demoralizing, cruel and mentally draining experience that paints a portrait of the lengths people will go to have what they want---the feelings and emotions of others be damned. Perfectly directed, wonderfully scripted and accurately performed, "Closer" is sure to get next to the deepest parts of your soul. 5 stars out of 5.

title: Open Mouth....
review:
Attracted by the stars, I watched this film without any read up and totally expected something a lot different! Especially considering the involvement of Julia Roberts and Natalie Portman.
