And to top it off - and I'm not trying to be a 'typical male', but Natalie Portman's scenes half way through the film made it that much more worth watching. Aside from that, the storyline itself was a great tale, and I hope to see another film of its caliber in the future.

As a last note - I was angry after I watched it the first time. Angry at the characters. The roles these two actresses played here... I was upset that they had taken those roles, and wish they hadn't. Yet, if they were not in the film, I don't see how it would have been as good as it was, and I also would not have a reason to have seen it (since I have had a crush on both actresses for so long I can't remember!).

If you haven't seen it, you should. It is a great movie!

title: Why do we relate to them?
review: The four principal characters are unsympathetic. They are selfish, promiscuous, even perverted, and yet we believe in them and sympathise with them. I believe that is the strength of 'Closer'. It gives us manipulative, callous characters and yet we relate to them because their flaws are human, their evils understandable. The most sympathetic character, Ms Portman's, actually turns out to be the most manipulative of them all. This film asks us to examine our dark halves, our own private perversions and selfishness. It asks us to examine the multiple natures of humanity. It's a manipulative film, definitely, but it's only reflecting the way we manipulate ourselves and those around us.

title: I've seen a lot, but this is surely one of my favourite of all times
review: I haven't seen much of Mike Nichols since this one, so it was a real surprise for me. A love story for adults and a cure for those who thought love was a simple thing you could easily play with it. Strangers,it's all about the ones we think to know, the people we love in vain, that we are sure to know and then in the end they weren't themselves for us. Magnificent performances by the actors, an excellent director, very intelligent dialogues and a simple script - my God, that's a masterpiece! i have no doubt about it. Some people may be reluctant about the movie and it did't won any Academy award. Well, if it was unfair for "Lost In Translation", is much more unfair for "Closer". Thank you Mike Nichols, one of the movies of my life.

title: don't get any closer
review: This movie tried hard to be intelligent and claim that mental capacity was the answer to overcome the temptation of jeopardizing relationships. If you are smart enough to realize this is not true, you probably weren't stupid enough to give the movie a try. For those of you who are, like me, not so bright, don't be fooled by this lavish attempt at convincing a bunch of horn-dogs that we're on a higher plane. Closer is nothing but cleverly disguised trailer trash, who are avoiding the realities of frail existence. May we all realize that every day we wake up is a mercy, not a playground for our privates. Julia Roberts is plain, and manly. Natalie Portman knows how wrong such a portrayal is, and Jude Law wishes he could come up with such snappy replies without poring over a script.

title: Thought Provoking But Theatrical
review:
Adapted from his own play by Patrick Marber, 'Closer' is without a shadow of a doubt the most theatrical film I have seen in a very long time. This isn't entirely a criticism, as it establishes a firm structure upon which plot and characterisation can be built. This skeleton is very leanly fleshed-out: there's a great economy of location, with each scene change advancing the narrative by many months, and we are provided with minimal information as to what has occurred in the lives of the principal characters in the intervening time. This, of course, means that the use of flashbacks  though rare  jars with the general tone and rhythm of the piece. A more cinematic re-structuring of Marber's script may have remedied this, but I fear greater fault lies in the rather pedestrian direction of Mike Nichols.

The performances are sound, particularly that of Clive Owen. Although unsubtle and aggressively (though not violently) sexual, there's an endearing earnestness to his character, Dan. Interestingly, he is the only character who is entirely open about his feelings, intentions and desires. He immediately admits to an infidelity, fully prepared to accept the consequences of his stupidity  and is outraged not by Julia Roberts's admission that she has been sleeping with Jude Law but by her deception of him. Marber clearly believes that Dan is a model for the modern honest sexual male  openly acknowledging his pornographic lusts  and this may be true, I suppose. Unfortunately Nichols direction, in spite of Owen's performance, renders Dan as a tragic-comic caricature much of the time.

A painfully flat performance by Julia Roberts  another one of Marber's bland women  doesn't help. She has only one outstanding scene, a vicious argument with Owen where she is forced to confess the sordid details of her liaison with Law. Even here, though, it's Owen who steals the moment with the glorious kiss-off line which it would be inappropriate to reprint here  but which I hope, in the course of some future failing relationship, to use.

Law is no more annoying than usual, and tries hard to turn on the charm. What could have been an interesting representation of a selfish moral coward verges all too often (and unsuccessfully) toward apologia.

Natalie Portman gives a capable turn, too, as Law's stripper girlfriend, Alice. All things to all men - Caesar's Wife in a sequined thong - she becomes an object of fascination for both Law and Owen (and briefly, artistically, for Roberts, though this is not developed). We are told that her wild sexual history was used as inspiration for the former's only novel and that, in her words, the only thing he missed out was "the truth", but we are, as an audience, told nothing of her past. A sexually obsessed Owen seeks her out, pays for her to strip for him, but becomes frustrated because she'll tell him nothing but the truth about herself and her sexuality  even if he is incapable of recognising it as such. She's cast in a variety of fantasy roles: Law's rescued waif and Owen's whore (Marber's Sphynx, perhaps?), but how far either is accurate is uncertain. Alice, I think, meant to be shaped as much by our own prejudices and preconceptions as she is by Portman's performance.

Portman is a strange choice for this role. She is a stunningly beautiful young woman, but  even when garbed in the most minimal pole-dancing garb  oddly nonsexual. She's like Audrey Hepburn in that regard. Perhaps the argument could be proffered for Alice as a modern-day Holly Golightly  both, after all, have mysterious pasts, work in areas of the sex-industry (though unlike Capote's Golightly there is no indication that Alice is, or ever has been, a prostitute) and have rather tortuous emotional relationships with their unsuccessful writer boyfriends.

'Closer' is a good play. It's not a bad film, but Nichols surprisingly fails to recognise it's essential un-cinematic nature.

title: Great movie with a great song at the end
review: I thought this was a great sexy movie. I just love Jude Law's and Clive Owen's characters in the movie. Natalie Portman was excellent. She is such a great actress. I really had wished that Alice and her boyfriend would have ended up together again. I love the song played at the end when everyone is looking back at Alice, which I think the title is can't take my eyes off of you. Can you tell me who sings this song. I would like very much to get this recording. On another comment someone had asked why everyone was looking at Alice. I think that was a great way to end the movie for Alice's character. She's confident and starting a new life for herself even though as I earlier commented I had wished they had worked things out.

title: Too Close to home!
review:
I was blown away by this movie. It continues to haunt me too. It's not very often when a film makes you think so much and do deep soul-searching. I really liked the story and the characters. It was so true... so real. I do think the title could have been better. Closer does not describe the experience. Something like "Brutal Honesty" or "RAW" would've been better suited.

The main thing that sticks with me about this movie is how anyone in their right mind could cheat on the gorgeous Natalie Portman! Yeah, yeah, it was with Julia Roberts, but come on! OK, you could say that Julia's character was a mature woman and Portman played a young, naive, flaky stripper. Fine, if you want to knit-pick!!! ;)

The other thing that I remember most about this movie is the intense conversations the jilted lovers had with each other! Men do ask those insane questions about sex. Why???? So crazy and yet so true.

The music and images at the beginning and ending are haunting...

title: I didn't like it when I saw it...
review: When I first heard about Closer I thought 'Oh God another romance flick!' So, I decided not to go and see it in the movies. Many of my friends did and they all loved it, but me being someone who doesn't like typical romances told them that I didn't want to see it or hear about it. A big mistake on my part! My ignorance meant I missed the experience of seeing this movie in the theatres. Finally, I went to rent some DVD's and it was there. I thought 'What's the harm?' So I rented it and watched it. But, not all of it, as it seemed slightly complex and I couldn't be bothered. Again, my ignorance served me badly. Finally, I got round to watching it properly. I thought it was OK, and it wasn't until I sat and read the quotes on this website that I realised just how funny this film was. Not only was it funny, but it was interesting and very well mad in my opinion. OK, so maybe it's a little confusing, but once I realised who was who and what was going on, I couldn't tear my eyes away. I love this movie now, I just wish I hadn't been such an idiot when it was first released!

title: 'real love'
review: One of the most realistic love stories I have ever seen. I can't say I'd call it a 'romantic comedy', although it has to do with romance and has plenty of good laughs in it. But the story does not follow that of a romantic comedy. It shows how love really is. I absolutely can't stand romantic comedies but this movie has become one of my favorites. I just love movies that make you think. And this story was so realistic- I watched it with my boyfriend and even he liked it. I could really relate to the plot. It shows that love is not perfect, the 'real' aspects of relationships, and that things don't always turn out to be what you want them to be. There are so many great lines in the movie that have stuck in my head. I absolutely loved Natalie Portman in this movie and can completely relate to her character.

title: No Spoiler's,...just True to Life!
review: This is real life folks,...Mike Nichol's has had his hand's on all the right 'trigger's' in almost every work of art he has done. And this my friends,...is a Life Work of Art! I have been in each situation,...and the screenplay just wreaks of realism. Unless of course you've never been there. I have and it almost hurts to watch certain scenes,...but it 'hit's the mark' on every one. And I don't care for Julia R. but she is beyond perfect here! If You've ever been hurt by a Lover, Wife, whatever. Life is pain,...only Love makes life worth living, and this movie rules in that department! Personally;...I could never have done what Dan did/does to Alice/Jane,...but I fall in love with Natalie Portman every time I see her,...and I'm head over heels for her in this one. A great tribute to Love & It's Frailty's. Check it out. But not for everyone,...especially kids under 16!!!!

title: I'm going to write a song about you...
review:
I'm going to write a song about you... it won't be about sex. yesterday I watched closer with my girl-friend. a lot of talking bout sex and a bad end for Jude Law. a pervert doctor with strange habits. Julia's voice is sweet. your play I mean your acting is lovely. will you ever listen to my song? Beautiful girl---maybe thats how I call the unwritten song :) Well...the movie is cold even it's about love and it's not your fault...damn it. The doctor is on the one hand a good guy.. loves honesty, strong man...but then so brutal. "Julia" is so mean. leavin him - leavin "Jude" He ends up with nothing...well at least he came with nothing :) Jane Jones sealed her and his destiny when telling him about how she leaves her boy friends. my English is so good. well that's nearly all. got no more time.

Good Bye

title: Discomforting and unreal, but compelling viewing
review:
I found this one of the most discomforting movies that I have seen for a long time. I revere Mike Nichols who has made some of the very best films of the last forty years. But Closer seemed in an alien style with dialogue and action that was unrealistic (maybe deliberately so) and a plot line that constantly made me want to say WHY? It is a film about lust and love without any actual sex scenes to speak of. That was quite smart of Nichols as it made us concentrate on the action and the screenplay rather than acting as voyeurs. I did not find the scene in the "Mens Club" (or whatever it was) particularly shocking, but what was Alice actually doing there? Played by Natalie Portman she was so delectable that you couldn't really believe that she would pass her days as a pole dancer! Julia Roberts made a reasonably believable photographer and there was some depth in her performance. But she didn't actually look particularly good (sorry Julia)! The key scene of the film is the cyber-sex scene and I frankly found it repulsive. Was it believable that the two male leads (Jude Law and Clive Owen) would get their kicks in this way? Not to me it wasn't, but perhaps I've lived a sheltered life.

Does the film seek to suggest that in the first decade of the 21st Century anything goes as far as relationships are concerned? That you can love (Dan says that he loves Alice) but still prowl and try and make it with someone you fancy within minutes of a meeting(Dan and Anna). I suppose that this may be the way of the modern world, but it is awfully cold and cynical and really loveless.

I rather wish I had not seen Closer for all its technical excellence and even given the pretty good performances by the four leads. It was an unsettling film and it left me confused rather than entertained.

title: a wicked, immoral but realistic story
review:
I have found the move to be somewhat disgusting. The movie contained two couples. They all cheated on each other with each other in evil and immoral ways. They said that they loved each other, but still acted as if the only thing the cared about was their own desires and temporary impulses.

The reason to why I gave this movie 6 points, is because it pointed out the negative consequences of infidelity. That's at least wthe only thing that I could make of it.

The language in the movie does not suit children or anyone sensitive for that matter.

title: Seems made for home viewing
review:
Considering how little physical action there is in this film, it is something of a minor miracle that 'Closer' works as effectively as it does. Patrick Marber's screenplay, adapted from his successful stage play, is built entirely on dialogue and the social interactions of four people. With a great cast and sex as the main theme, fireworks are bound to go off.

I did not see 'Closer' when it was released in theatres, deciding to watch it on DVD. While I do not know what kind of experience the movie is on a big screen, there is a level of intimacy that makes it seem ideal for watching alone in the living room. This film is about four out-of-the-ordinary people who are in bizarre relationships, yet call for our own self-examination. Marber's writing is not kind; it is a brutal portrayal of how sex can be used to establish personal territory and hurt others. There are definitely connections between Marber and the work of two other playwrights, Harold Pinter (especially 'Betrayal') and Edward Albee, who hold similar views on intimacy and the use of language (or absence of it) to maintain power.

Besides watching Natalie Portman and Julia Roberts take on completely new persona, it is a major surprise to see all four marquee actors work so well as a group. This is the type of film where one actor's talents can overwhelm an entire cast. Portman and Clive Owen, in my opinion, stand out the most, but never does one actor seem to be looking for an upper hand over the remaining three. There is wide debate as to whom the best and worst 'moral' characters are, which owes to the fine balance in Marber's writing and the excellent direction of Mike Nichols.

Date movie seekers beware, do not see! You may be banging your head against a wall afterwards. Recommended for solitary viewing with a very open mind. Also be aware that the Columbia Pictures DVD does not offer much in the way of extras. 'Closer' is presented in anamorphic widescreen format only with English and French subtitles. Besides a standard trailer, the disc carries a music video of Damien Rice's 'The Blower's Daughter,' Closer's main theme.

*** ½ out of 4

title: Not Your Average Love Story
review:
With movies like "The Notebook" coming out, it annoyed me that all these movies had a typical "happily ever after" ending. Yes, I'm only 16, but I want to see what relationships are truly like, not the sugar coated versions. Then I rented Closer. A couple of my friends tried to talk me out of it, saying it was too crude, not realistic and just hands down horrible. Thankfully, I didn't listen to them. I'm not going to summarize it, because others already have, but this is what I wanted to see in movies. Closer is sharp witted, sad, and crude, but this is exactly what I wanted to see.

I've seen almost every Julia Roberts movie out there, but this one is probably my favourite. This is not the average Julia Roberts movie. Her one scene with Clive Owen made me hold my breath. As for Clive, he is spectacular here. So is Natalie Portman. This is Natalie's breakthrough role. Her portrayal of Alice is so real, it's hard to imagine her as a character. Jude Law's Dan annoyed me, honestly, but he played the character well, as he usually can't annoy me. I'm glad I didn't take my friends advice on this one. This is a movie that can't be missed

title: A series of perfectly true moments.
review:
If you're looking for an exciting Hollywood blockbuster then this film is not for you. Its slow, and at times seems as if it is going nowhere. I watched this film four weeks ago, at first i didn't like it, but I can't stop thinking about it, and the more i think about it the more i come to appreciate it. People seem to have drastic reactions to this film, they either love is because its so realistic or hate it for the same reason.

If you let it this film will move you more than you thought possible. If you have ever had a bad relationship or even an average relationship then watch this film.You will find within this film several moments that are so perfectly true and honest that they're painful to watch.

title: At the end of the film I had the sensation that love doesn't last or exists and people's alter ego are powerful and more attractive to some women
review:
As I said before , I think the characters were so cold or unable to love ,they were dominated by desire and body needs instead of feelings, affect and real love.

No-one of them knew what they want, but at the same time, they had a certain consciousness of their negative personality features.

The best role , in my opinion, was made by Natalie Portman, she was real,beautiful and the "winner" in this story , because she behaved as she really looked like. On the other hand, Dan was the weakest of them . He was so unsure of himself, he never knew who he was really in love with: Anna or Alice . Spectators think events make him decide , and in the end he was the "looser".

title: NOT a feel good movie!
review:
Supposedly, this movie portrays us human beings as who we *really* are. All in all this movie paints a far too negative picture. It's not a love story; merely a study about human relationships, with lots of cynical undertones.

The acting is (apart from Portman's performance) mediocre. Cinematography is quite good. I loved the music.

If you believe all people are like this... you're in for a surprise. Don't be a cynic you're wasting your time.

Summing things up (want to keep it short after so much said about it), it's a feel-bad movie. As such quite rare from the Hollywood factories. Be warned.

title: Weird!
review:
I had a movie session with my girlfriend a while ago, and we happen to stumble upon this piece of movie. It was her choice, and I know that I hadn't picked it if I had to choose. :-) Anyhow, this movie starts out rather weird and it contains a lot of jumping in the chronology, which was quite easy to follow for me (even though I thought it was quite weird) but my girlfriend was facing a hard time at times trying to follow the jumping in the chronology. Natalie Portman makes an excellent performance here (as usual) and really blends this movie. The performances by Jude Law and Clive Owen are OK, but I think that Julia Roberts makes one of her less good performances here.

The movie didn't really turn out to be an awful movie as I first expected by judging it from its first 30 minutes, and I have to admit that it settled a weird feeling in me that it was somehow OK, but I didn't really like it at all. The piece contains a few surprises for the analytic trying-to-predict freak, which were to my pleasure. But generally this weren't something I connected well with at all. 5/10, and those 5 points are just because of the neat acting here.

title: A flawed musical beds - but what does it mean?
review:
Closer is trying to say something profound, but who knows what. It's a case of style over substance - a "much ado about nothing".

An anti-feminist movie, with two thoroughly unlikeable men, one silly woman (Roberts), and an OK, but naive(?) fourth (Portman). The women are just chess-pieces being played by the men, and seem quite content reacting to their manipulated status. No empowerment, insight or intelligence. Maybe this is real life, where women just cannot help themselves, poor things.

Quite a tedious movie about a pointless subject, lots of talking about pointless subjects and debating about pointless subjects, meaningful looks, bed-hopping, lying, deceit. There is very little character sympathy developed - as each character is completely indulgent and fails to exercise restraint or discipline.

This mediocre picture is not helped by gratuitous attempts to give the characters some vague backgrounds: Roberts is a (mediocre) photographer, who seems to live by the rule that a crap picture is better if its enlarged, Portman is a stripper (now that's worth the rental fee!) and Owen is a doctor of some sort. Most contrived, Law is an obituary writer. Maybe he could write an obituary about his nearly dead career, having been in turkey after turkey recently.

On the plus side, it's good to see Julia Roberts in an understated "Adult" role, and she shows that she can excel in a good dramatic role. Portman isn't too bad, and Jude Law and Clive Owen just go through the motions. Well, the male characters did OK, given the weakness in their scripts.

title: David Jeffers
review: Closer reveals the beautiful people being beautiful, or, lying liars and their lies. Another Mike Nichols portrayal of beauty in emotional distress, i.e.; Ann Margaret, Katherine Ross, Annette Benning, Sandy Dennis, Stockard Channing, Meryl Streep. A story of attraction and repulsion, Closer is well photographed with an interesting story and great casting. Urban London is a wonderful setting. From Nichols, who directed several of the finest American films of the '60s and '70s some of the most atrocious and embarrassingly bad dialog I can remember. All four characters are dishonest with each other and themselves, conniving, manipulative, and tormented by their own awful, immoral behavior. When Julia Roberts and Jude Law first kiss she presses the shutter release on the cable she is holding as though it's a metaphoric climax. I actually laughed out loud. Portman is the star of what could be her breakout film. The story also concludes well. Law's character is alone and discovers Portman's waif was never honest or really trusted him. Carnal Knowledge has been one of my favorite films since I first saw it in the seventies. There are similarities that would make this a suitable bookend to Nichol's career. Well worth seeing but by no means a major film.

title: Not close enough
review:
"I love you... No I love her... Or do I love you? No, it's her... I mean you... Er..." Oh, who gives a stripper's thong about these people anyway? They deserve one another. Sure, they're all quick with the banter but one's guy's a weakling, the other's a bastard, the girls are both incredibly fickle and none of them can make their minds up.

This is a well-acted but rather smug film which offers little insight into 21st century sex and relationships. Like its characters, Closer just manipulates others with its hollow emotions and pseudo-cleverness.

And anyway, a self-proclaimed American 'waif' like Alice  with no luggage, job or place to stay  would never have made it through customs in the first place. Yet we're supposed to believe that the British Immigration Service happily allow her to stay for four years. Or do they hand out green cards to waitresses and strippers now? Sorry to be pedantic, but if a film wants to be taken seriously

title: attention to sex, and lots of it
review:
Legendary director Mike Nichols turns his attention to sex, and lots of it, in the highly controversial Closer. The entire cast is full of Academy Award nominees and winners including Jude Law, Julia Roberts, Natalie Portman, and Clive Owen (rumored to be the next James Bond). The story revolves around four strangers who make one another's lives miserable as they continually love and cheat on one another. This is a very chatty film, but luckily for Nichols the screen writing by Patrick Marber is so jaw-dropping that it could keep the focus of an auditorium full of attention deficit disorder teens for the entire hour and forty minutes.

All four bring very different personalities to their characters, some who lead a false existence and others that are so brutally honest with one another that it is scary. It seems like an ultimate showdown between real and fake in the dangerous game of commitment. I love the overall message and tone of the film, as Nichols shows how easy it is to love and even easier to lose.

I couldn't help but shake my head at some of the things I heard from this film, some of it actually making me laugh because of its excessive use. Of all the talent, I was surprised by Julia Roberts the most in this film. You just don't expect her to be as controlled and fragile as she is in this role. But, it's Julia Roberts, and she pulls it off. All of the unfaithfulness seems to take a shot at the "flighty" high school and college generation we live with.

Boy loves girl. Girl loves boy. Boy and Girl move in together. They cheat on each other. Boy and Girl hate one another. Repeat.

title: Not close enough
review:
Wish I stayed further away.

It's full of all this b.s. about relationships and animalistic behaviors and mind games and violence and typical everyday crapola that we all deal with and one point or another all throughout life.

Then we either give up sex altogether or get married or neither or both or become the hooker with a golden heart or call Mike Nichols and say you're a dirty old man.

Yeah, we're all a bunch of used cars, I get it.

Now show me Queen Amidala on the ass-pole again.

6 out of 10. A D+.

title: Sad, sad, sad with no happy ending!
review:
Please don't watch this unless you're some dour type who likes sad endings, so-called arty attempts at impact by so-called moving scenes and subtle -- but too subtle -- plots.

I hope I missed something in Jane calling herself Alice, I hope I did. I don't think I did. I wanted there to be a happy ending, I wanted things to explain why previous events had bothered to occur. Most soaps (and they really are low-brow) have plots that sometimes result in events turning out as they were before, but I like my films to go somewhere; to surprise me and maybe to give me something to think about. They should always have a clear raison d'etre, however, and this film don't have one (SiC)! If you want to watch a film and you want to watch something serious, that is your choice, but don't want a film that makes you want to rant as I have done in this comment. Normally, I write carefully and consider my words and the order they are delivered. This film has annoyed me and I want you to be saved from having to suffer it.

I am sure, however, that there are people (in fact I know by its rating) that like this sort of film. I just ask you to try and enjoy life. Embrace amusing, light-hearted and rewarding films. For goodness sake, watch Around The World in 80 Days with Jackie Chan and look on the bright-side!

title: More style than substance
review:
possible mild spoilers ahead . . .

To be fair, 'Closer' is only rarely painful to watch, and though I found myself loathing most of the characters, they held my interest. The actors are engaging and attractive--especially Clive Owen as the oddly sympathetic Larry and Natalie Portman as Alice, the one character who doesn't seem to deserve the misery that befalls her--and though the settings seem a little excessively hip (big, airy London flats; upscale art gallery; high end, 'gentleman's club'-type strip joint, etc.), this is the movies, after all: even in non-escapist fare, we audiences prefer to watch people who are better looking than us, have cooler wardrobes and haircuts, and hang out in the land of the beautiful people, looking perfect, sipping champagne, smoking French cigarettes, and talking about serious stuff like art, literature, and, of course, sex.

The trouble with 'Closer' is false advertising. The title of the film and play itself suggest that the story will be about intimacy, but the screenplay keeps the audience at arm's length. We open with the chance meeting of Alice, a precocious American tramp meant to fit the 'La Boheme' archetype (she actually refers to herself as 'a waif'), and Dan, another big, black-and-white stock character--the struggling artist, confined to an unrewarding job as a writer of obituaries for a London newspaper. The melodramatic soundtrack does the work of informing us that these two have made an instant connection of epic, Romeo-and-Juliet, Tristan-and-Isolde proportions. We learn that Alice is fresh off the plane from NYC, where she has left both a problem boyfriend and her job as a stripper (yet another of an endless string of clichés that mar this film). Dan self-effacingly reveals his deep desire to be a successful novelist.

But before we get a chance to see these characters gain some depth below type, we are propelled one or two years into the future. Dan has sold his first novel--borrowing shamelessly from the presumably colorful life of Alice, who is now his girlfriend and flat-mate--and is being photographed for the novel's dust-jacket by Anna (Julia Roberts), to whom he finds himself inexplicably and overwhelmingly attracted (hey, Julia's hot, no doubt, but would she really knock Natalie Portman off the pedestal that easily?), particularly after he learns she's been up all night reading a galley copy of his book. We know so little about Dan that the sincerity of his attraction can't really be known; his first scene with Alice suggests that he's a shy, unassuming fellow, but with no indication of what has taken place between his meeting with Alice and his session with Anna, we have no reason to think he doesn't flirt with every attractive woman he meets. Alice arrives, instantly senses the attraction between Dan and Anna, provokes a bizarre but arresting confrontation with Anna . . .

And then once again we are flung into the unspecified future, where Larry (Clive Owen), a dermatologist who occupies himself with pornography and on-line sex chat, is cruelly lured by Dan (posing as a horny female swinger named 'Anna') into confronting the real Anna at her favorite place to relax, the London Aquarium. Lo and behold, the two hit it off (though one might suspect that Anna's initial interest in Larry might be fueled by a desire to get back at Dan for the sadistic joke).

We jump ahead haphazardly again and again, and it's safe to say without giving anything away that the sexual tension between Dan and Anna eventually comes to a head, after which bad things ensue. We then get the pleasure of watching our pretty, serious actors berate each other in vulgar, bitter exchanges. Jealousy and resentment abound; the wronged lovers Larry and Alice have their own encounter when Larry stumbles drunkenly into the club where Alice works after having left Dan (with Natalie Portman proving once again that the best ways for a pretty girl to get an Oscar nomination are either to wear a fake nose or play a stripper/whore). I assume we're meant to be filled with admiration for these 'courageous' performances, but even pretty, serious actors can't make us sympathize with these despicable characters. Julia Roberts gives the subtlest, most restrained performance, but we're never given any indication of what Anna sees in either Dan or Larry. Clive Owen's Larry is probably the most interesting character--a relatively sympathetic nice guy with a dark, misogynistic streak and a penchant for rough sex and porn. Dan seems sweet in the first scene, but then proceeds to behave monstrously, so that you find yourself hoping he'll get his well-earned comeuppance.

The structure of the film seems like the sort of device that might work well on stage, but on film, the audience is too distant from the characters' inner lives. Furthermore, Mike Nichols chooses here to take the melodramatic route, overusing Damien Rice's maudlin pop confectioneries to overstate the seriousness and importance of what's happening, so much so that we feel as if we're being pounded over the head with the film's deep seriousness, when in fact it's a rather simple story about shallow, selfish people betraying each other.

The real trouble here is that, despite the rare opportunity to see Natalie Portman bending over in a thong and Julia Roberts comparing the flavors of her two lovers' sperm samples, this film has nothing new to say about contemporary love relationships. Deception destroys trust, love is soured by jealousy, vindictiveness is ruinous . . . don't we already know this? Alice summarizes the situation appropriately early on in the film: when Dan lamely apologizes for having fallen in love with Anna with the classic 'I didn't mean for this to happen' line, Anna succinctly reminds him that 'there's always a moment' when one can choose to resist temptation--to suppress his/her own desires or perceived needs and avoid betraying trust. This one scene renders the rest of the film superfluous.

title: Really good film worth going out of your way for!
review: I thought this was an excellent film! It really had a lot of twists and turns that were unexpected! Everybody's character was really good. The cast stars Julia Roberts, Natalie Portman, Jude Law , and Clive Owen. This movie had some good scenes with plot to it and drama rally filled the viewers mind as to the story. I really thought they could've cast a different person to play Julia Robert's character. The story takes place in London, England but Julia Roberts is an American. I didn't understand why they cast her! The movie really takes off from the beginning and doesn't let up until the final credits! I was really on my edge of my seat!

title: An impressive spectacle of personal feelings
review: Closer is one of those beautiful movies which can be compared with, beautiful girls, singles, we don't live here anymore and some other great movies, but with a clear presents of the hurt that's been done to each other and the games there're played. Closer drags you in self-reflection, with a beautiful cast, a great dialog and a beautiful story about four people who's lives cross each other. I saw the movie late in the evening and it held my thoughts going for a while afterward. It is a good thing that these movies are made and that these stories are being told.....it will hold a mirror up and the reality in your face.

title: Why waste the time to write a review about a feature as trivial as "Closer"
review:
The justifications for spending any more time on this movie than watching it are two: First, I have lots of spare time, and second, it gives me something to do to try to come up with a second reason.

That said, the only character of any interest is the doctor, Clive Owen. The character seems sort of genuine and Owen is convincing in the role. Unfortunately, even his character seems to be a thawed out freeze dried shell of a human being, a circumstance certainly true of the other three characters. Of those three, why did the makers of this minor venture get Julia Roberts to play such an unchallenging role? That seems among the most blatant wastes of talent in a long time until one views the Willem Defoe role in Bill Murray's insomnia curing "The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou". Now, Natalie Portman is definitely a treat for male eyes, and maybe the same could be said of Jude Law for the female gender, however, the movie is too simple to take in any sort of serious way, and possibly because of its foppishness can not be seen as offensive as "Sideways". At any rate, if you are in the mood to see a marginally amusing c- attempt at romantic comedy (or maybe even seriousness) with a decently written character and young pretty people, "Closer" could be an alternative to consider.

title: substance please
review: I'm sorry to all of you who believe that you've witnessed a masterpiece because I had some serious problems with this film. At no point did I get any reason whatsoever for why these characters are so madly in love with each other. Nothing of their personalities is really examined because all of their conversations are about one thing and one thing only, Sex. Please, if anyone can prove me wrong and say that there was actually some substance to the characters relationships besides sex I'd be glad to read it, because I don't think it's possible. My main problem with the film is Julia Roberts character, who for all of my understanding has little to no qualities, at least expressed in the film, that would bring two men to fall so helplessly in love with her, pretty smile aside. I can't believe Roberts as an artist, actually taking the photographs and I cant understand why such an integral part of the story is based around those talents, because ultimately it is completely irrelevant to her actions. She isn't kind, or caring, or understanding, and she certainly isn't a morally fit human being. WHY are they in love with her? The reason is never clear because she has no redeeming qualities, pretty hair aside. I can't say that Roberts did a bad job, and I do respect her work, but she didn't have a whole hell of a lot to work with, besides two very talented actors in Clive Owen and Jude Law. The character killed the movie for me because she is NOT lovable, and the story is based around two men obsessively in love with her. Oh, wait, I must be a moron, it was love at first sight, doesn't that just clear up the whole thing.

title: Yawn!
review: Very overrated. I mean, we have to spend five minutes watching-literally watching-Jude Law exchange dirty I'm's??? This movie makes it seem as if Natalie and Julia are only two ladies in the world. Totally ridiculous, and, may I add, predictable. How many places have names of heroes who saved others?? Julia Roberts seems bored and unmotivated during the whole movie. Jude Law is OK, and Natalie Portman is sexy. She is the best par of the movie. Definitely a movie geared more for women, and definitely one that will have guys scratching their heads after. To be fair, there was some decent parts. But you have to get past the first grueling 20 minutes (Sllllooooowwww) to get there.

title: To love a cheater.
review:
Yes this movie may seem shallow and perverted, but in all honesty I can relate.

Well the blunt sex talk and the words "cream", "wank", etc. don't apply to me.

However I was thee Alice Ayres in the movie.

I love this movie on the basis of what love is. Forgiveness, compromise, mistakes, the willingness to be vulnerable and perhaps to be hurt by the one you love. I really liked Larry aside from his "cave-man"nistic talk.

And I loved Natalie Portman. "I don't love you anymore." "Since when?" "Since now." That takes strength. Plain and simple. Alice will love you like nobody will love you, give you a break if you make a mistake, but after that if you mess up again, she's gone bye-bye.

Anyways in conclusion, if your a sappy and heart-broken, you'll love this movie. It'll help you decided if you wanna be like Larry or Alice in a relationship.

title: Nice try
review:
The story was very good, but the film made too many compromises with casting that it ultimately fell flat.

Natalie Portman wants to be in the film, but she's not willing to do what it requires in terms of playing a stripper. It's not that she's a bad actress. I thought she handled the emotional scenes very well.

And then there's Julia Roberts. I'm not saying that she shouldn't be allowed to do things outside her 'Pretty Woman' thing. It's just that she wants to have her cake and eat it too. Her idea of making her character more vulnerable was to not wear as much makeup.

Jude Law can do his pretty-boy cruel shtick with his eyes closed. He wasn't miscast, just too predictable. And what was with all the weeping? They even got Clive to do the boo-hoos. Clive was pretty amazing as the doctor. He was the only believable one in the cast.

Cheers!

title: Reality of Men
review:
Actual love story revealing a thing or two about men. The thing i like about this movie is it's reality. It shows what men really care about when woman cheat. Man rather would like to see their girl cheat with someone who isn't that great in bed then someone with a big c*ck f*cking the brains out of your girlfriend. It is a guy thing. So woman out there, if you want to understand us try this movie. At the beginning you would expect a cliché love story but it turns out to be a bit different. It also sketches the woman who can't make up their mind (roberts) and beautiful girls LETTING abuse themselves (portman) and end up nowhere. And about the guys, the emotional ones (law) can't handle woman so eventually he gets girlfriend-less and the brutal 100% man figure (owen) who just wants p*ssy who gets all the girls. It's funny but the film actually shows why woman want to suppressed..

see it yourself

title: Great movie
review: One of the best movies iv seen in years. Although the story line did not sound appealing at first, you get so involved in all the love affairs you can't help but to enjoy the the entire movie. Clive Owen and Natalie Portman give their best performances ever as supporting actors (actress). Although Julie Roberts and Jude Law did not earn any praise for their work, their acting was still top notch. Filled with memorable quotes,breath taking acting, and beautiful actresses (once you see Natalie Portman walking down the street at the end of the movie, you'll understand), this movie will be loved by all those who enjoy the casual vulgar movie. If this doesn't sound like your kind of movie, pick something from the Disney section.

title: Near perfect movie!!
review: If you are searching for a chick flick or romance of sorts, this definitely isn't the film to turn to. This is a high drama that will uplifts and then brings you way down. It's a very down-to-earth story about people. An intriguing story about love, passion,pain, jealousy, honesty and commitment between 4 peoples, Dan, Alice, Anna and Larry. This movie is amazing. The storyline is very slow but the dialogs are very strong. So if you don't pay enough attention to the dialog you'll definitely miss the feeling of the story. All of the cast is brilliant, they successfully brought this movie alive. I can say that this is a near perfect movie. But I don't recommend this movie for you to watch on your first date ^_^

title: WOW! - a perfect film!
review: I saw this movie a long time ago, but writing about it now. An excellent film. It is probably one of my favorite movies of all time. The movie had some really good things to back it up. First, an excellent story - it was flawless. Second, perfect casting - Jude, Julia, Natalie, and Clieve were just perfect for their roles and it felt like it was they own lives and the role was just tailor made for them! Third - an excellent director - many good stories are not told right simply because of direction; however, in Closee one definitely does not have to worry about that. If you are a type of person that enjoys different types of movies (and I don't mean they have to be Oscar winning - but simply those that have good stories and directed flawlessly and have the perfect casting) Well, then Closer is definitely a MUST SEE!! I was very mad that Closer wasn't even nominated for an Oscar, but at least some of performances were. Last year, I had three favourite films including Sideways, Million Dollar Baby, Closer was definitely my third one!

title: There are no likable characters, but an interesting movie if you like watching people cheat.
review:
Set primarily in London, "Closer" has only four characters who matter to the story. Natalie Portman is young New Yorker Alice (or maybe Jane?), new in London, and who has a chance meeting with Dan (Jude Law). Maybe it is because she was looking left instead of right at the intersection and is hit by the vehicle. Dan is a London newsman, his job is writing obituaries for the newspaper. Julia Roberts is a bit daring as Anna , a photographer. Quite by different accident, Dermatologist Larry (Clive Owen) comes into Anna's life, then they all come into each other's lives, for better or for worse. Mostly for worse. None of them are "model" people, and Larry is certainly not what you would want your doctor to be, or maybe your doctor is! How would you know? Interesting character studies, but with no likable characters, I found myself a bit unconcerned after it ended.

SPOILERS. Portman seemed intent on shattering her "girl" image and here plays a stripper, in some very revealing costumes. Roberts also plays against her usual roles, as here she cheats sexually willingly. Larry surfs the internet when he can, looking for dirty-talking young girls for sex. Angry that Anna put him off, Dan pretends to be a horny girl and lures Larry to the aquarium to meet Anna, as retribution. But Anna and Larry hit it off, and eventually get married. But Anna still has groans for Dan and she cheats. Larry is controlling, and by sheer will gets Alice in bed. Each in turn destroys the confidence and love of the other. At the end, Alice returns to New York, we see on her passport that she really is Jane.

title: Closer
review:
Closer is one of the most interesting films I have ever seen. The four main characters are not really nice people - especially not to each other - and yet they are very intriguing. The story is basically about 4 people who happen to meet each other under very weird circumstances. The story continues through several sexual betrayals that are dealt with very bluntly and realistically. That is really all I can say about the plot without giving too much away.

Two of the performances from this movie have been nominated for several awards and they were definitely deserving. Natalie Portman plays, in my opinion, the most interesting character - Alice - and it is the first time I have seen her in a very "adult" role. She holds her own amongst established actors that are all older than she is. Clive Owen, as Larry, is unbelievable. He is, at the same time, the character that delivers the harshest lines - they make you want to squirm in your seat due to their personal nature - and yet he is also a character that you find you want to succeed. The best scenes in the film are between these two actors and I think they deserved all of the awards they received (and should have gotten more!)It is worth it to see Closer just for their acting.

Jude Law is good, but his character, Dan, is just not the most interesting one. I found that I didn't really invest too much in him. Unfortunately, the big problem for me was Julia Roberts as Anna. She, once again, plays her typical "Julia Roberts" character, although in this case she doesn't smile at all. She is so boring that myself and the person I watched the film with couldn't understand why the men were so interested in her. Her character has a little "kink" that I didn't even realize until Clive Owen's character spells it out later in the film. I know I am in the minority when it comes to Julia Roberts. I just don't think she is all that good. She's certainly not terrible, but when compared to the excellence of the other three in Closer she becomes a massive drag factor to the film.

Like I said, the people in this film do awful things to each other an yet I found myself really interested in their stories. While there is no sex on screen that I can remember, the dialogue is very sexually graphic and very personal. If you have problems with this then Closer is not the film for you. I, however, thought it was one of the best written, best acted, most intriguing movies I have seen in a very long time. Excellent film!

title: Fascinating, well acted & directed movie
review:
A non-operatic somewhat feminist variation on the theme of Mozart's "Cosi fan Tutte", in which all four characters play interchangeable roles in love relationships. It really doesn't matter who ends up with whom. Natalie Portman and Clive Owen fully deserved their awards. Mike Nichols direction was great--keeping the action flowing and the audience guessing. Julia Roberts and Jude Law were wonderful, playing against type as secondary characters in the piece.

The background music was excellent. I was somewhat confused as to the movie's intent until hearing the excerpt from "Cosi fan Tutte" and everything fell into place.

The ending which allows one character to break away from the dance and reveal that she was playing a duplicitous game almost throughout, was stunning.

I thoroughly enjoyed this film and feel it deserves many viewings.

title: Horrible!
review:
This movie makes the assumption that when beautiful people, who are complete strangers, get together, they immediately kiss and fall in love. It amazes me that so many people comment of the realism of this film. It could not be farther from reality (unless you expand the definition to include "Reality" dating shows.) Where do we see that these people would ever fall in love with each other? They meet and then they are all in love. Not one frame of this movie is devoted to the how or why they fall in love. "You're pretty, I'm pretty" leads to sex not love. We are not even shown when the couples get back together. We have to hear it from the characters mouths. Is that suppose to be exposition? Making up is the low hanging fruit of any love story. They couldn't even write this in? A myriad of factors go into falling in love. Not the least of which is the test of time. This makes writing love into a movie very difficult, but there are several examples of it being done successfully. To call this a "reality based" love story discredits films like "Eternal Sunshine" and "When a Man Loves a Woman". Yes, even the sci-fi movie "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind" does a better job of showing us a true picture of two people in love than this movie does.

The final collection of scenes (especially the hotel scene with Portman and Law) were pretty good and provided some redemption for the film. However, the final scene with her walking down the street and all the guys' heads turning was really bad. What are we supposed to believe that she is "beautiful" and empowered now? She's Natalie Portman! When in this film was she not beautiful? If you want to see the transformation of a female character from self conscious and meek to strong and empowered (and therefore beautiful on that merit alone) then look to Whoopie Goldberg's character in the Color Purple.

title: Deep, very deep
review: An excellent movie, it is not what you would like to see...it is what you have to see, really deep. When I saw the movie for the first time I was a bit disappointed because some friends told me that it is cool (I was not very attentive at first)anyway the soundtrack was extraordinary so I had to listen to it again. Just after listening to the soundtrack carefully I finally understood what was really going on there, so try to understand because it is deep.... The actors are really good especially Jude Law, he is born to be that character, but honestly I liked Clive Owen better, he had a better role probably that is way but still he was good to. The only word that can define this movie is DEEP!!!

title: Not Exactly an Uplifting Film
review:
As much as I appreciate good acting and good storytelling, I also want to root for somebody in a film and not feel completely depressed afterward. "Closer" exhibits some wonderful acting indeed. The four leads are terrific and Natalie Portman in a very adult role, is especially good. My problem with this movie is that I hated everyone. These are four of the most unhappy people I've come across in a long time. They're all entwined in troubled relationships and frankly all four of them deserve each other.

The acting is terrific. The story is very well written and the diologue is OK. I just didn't care. This is not a feel good story about romance and relationships. If anything, it'll make you question yours. (**)

title: OK, Natalie's hot, but what's the point?
review:
Um, can someone tell me the point of this movie? I thought it was going to be a deep study into the problems of obsession and jealousy, but instead it seemed more like a study on how shallow and idiotic some people can be. I mean, we never once come to understand anyone's true motives and never once did I believe that any of the characters really loved anyone or anything. If that was the intention of the filmmakers, I guess I just don't see the purpose in that concept. How does a 2 dimensional take on relationships help anyone in this world? I just don't get it...

Just seemed like the whole thing was more of an ode to "Look how gorgeous Natalie Portman is" - and that's all well and good, but how does that make a difference in this world of love and marriage? Not a dang thing IMO. Boy... I really could use a shower after that film! Blah!

title: Strangers
review:
No spoilers here, so read on.

I found this completely riveting to watch. And with great performances from all of the players. And at some point I like the framing, the tightening up slowly on character's faces. I'm n0t sure if Mike Nichols is a trendy director, but I do know he is a veteran and I enjoy his previous works that I've seen. But I guess it only does get trendy if he starts using the rack-focus, and I don't seem to remember that being used in the movie.

Very entertaining. Especially the chatroom exchange between Larry and Dan, and the ultimate payoff, it is foreshadowed but very subtly in the beginning. A nice little twist in the end. Although why the character did it? Never quite clear what her motives were for doing it, but you'll know what I mean when you see the film.

It's worth watching. If n0t, a rental....

title: Amazingly complex and interesting.
review: True, it was not a "happily ever after" movie... but the complexity and raw human emotion shown so poignantly I found captivating. I am unable to shake it from my head even now, 2 weeks later. There is an honesty spoken within the film, that if you open your mind, you will surely see. It definitely shows the many flaws of humanity, but then again, there are many flaws in humanity. It involves 4 very disturbed people in a sort-of bizarre love square. All four of them spend time torturing, and being tortured in an emotional way... but they are all quite unique. I think you just have to see this film, it could not have been made any better. And when you do, you will feel, and you will think. Can you ask anything more from a movie?

title: A mature, realistic depiction of relationships
review:
Well it doesn't matter what I was looking for in the movie but few things impressed me. I think the strength of the movie lies in it's complicated storyline. When you think about relationships, feelings are far more complicated then could ever be depicted on silver screen. There are always stereotypes and a love-story is full of such things.

There is always some sense of idealism put into it, I don't know- may be because it makes things more dramatic and movies watchable. This movie seems to be a fresh change.

Story may not sound realistic, but it shows you the face of reality to the extent of depress you, but thats how much depressing things may become in life. Characters couldn't be more real than this. Performances were good! A must watch for a serious movie lover.

title: Closer
review: (First of all, excuse my English)I don't actually believe that this film deserves the maximum qualification, I just chose that so it to have a greater average qualification, anyway, I do believe this film is perfect, I have written a gigantic review (which is in Spanish and I don't feel like to translate it right now) but I will say that the movie has really original things like the way its directed (which resembles a play) the performances and the way the actors make you realize the very nature of the human being. The dialogs which are "honest", although the characters don't like it... I don't remember now, I will say though that this is not a film for all audiences, people who are really narrow minded or conservative will find it chocking, but this is because that kind of people doesn't like the truth of the things (maby they are scared of it)

title: Absolute Monkey Dung
review: This movie blows. The only reason someone would claim to have enjoyed it is because they couldn't understand it and figured that must mean it was good. I've always thought movies were supposed to be compelling, thought provoking. I've used deodorant more intriguing than this. Here you have a film all about sex and relationships but without sex and relationships. There's no realism, everything you see or feel is told to you, not shown or expressed. You're fed some dialogue and through that everything is to be "believed" or "realized." I guess this is what happens when you try to turn a play into a motion picture. Unfortunately, it doesn't work. A major failure.

title: Faithful to the unfaithful
review: Is your boyfriend stepping out on the relationship? Wife cheating? Bring them to "Closer" and watch them squirm. Some movies are perfect for couples falling in love. Recommend this one to snarling friends on the verge of breaking up; they'll see themselves -- and their soon-to- be former lovers -- in the four characters. "Closer" and "Sideways" provide two excellent ensembles, four actors in each exploring the boundaries of what can and cannot be accepted in relationships. A warning: Those who are in sold relationships may walk away shaken -- in a good way, of course. If you didn't see "Closer" in the theaters, rent the movie and watch it over and over.

title: Not too bad
review:
I give this movie points on everything that a movie requires, in order to be entertaining. However, where it lacked, I believe, is in it's storyline and plot. The direction was right on. The scenes were well planned and the time lapses were pretty intriguing. The acting was done very well by all, especially Natalie Portman. I normally don't care for Clive Owen, and even though I was 'supposed' to like him... I thought he did very well, also. Jude Law was right on, and Julia Roberts was OK.

Cinematography was nicely done and pleasing to the eye. The emotions of relationship turmoil was portrayed expertly by all.

I would have liked to have seen this quality of performance and direction done with a better story. All did fine with what they had to work with, but the story just wasn't as interesting as I had thought it would be, given the topic. Also, the ending lacked much to be desired. Without closure and without a sense of satisfaction. However, I've seen worse.

title: Ah, schadenfreude
review:
Many people have commented that they found the characters unbelievable, yet I can think of more than one person who has been in all four points of this polygon. Only one thing seemed completely implausible, namely that Alice had no contacts with her earlier life, or lives, and that no one found this suspicious.

Part of the pleasure (if you happen to be someone who enjoyed Closer) was that you know just how dreadful each situation could get, and yet it got worse.

Each rotten action of these unlikable cads made me cringe in remembrance of similar behaviour on my part.

Definitely worth it.

title: Modern fairytale...
review:
The story involves four persons that meet under normal and not so normal conditions. Somehow all these people get their life's tangled up with each other and forms a very dark and hurting story.

So this movie should not be seen just after a painful breakup or if you are in a relationship that is on the edge of disaster. Because this movie really makes you think and feel. And if you have no experience of heart ace and love this movie should mean nothing to you.

The casting is great. The story is great. But I have to admit that some parts of the movie felt really boring. So, this isn't a great movie. Just a pretty good one. And that is if you like drama movies.

title: Good acting can't save this movie
review:
Watching these morally bankrupt characters go about their lives is similar to, but less interesting than, watching ants in an ant farm. That's how detached from them I felt.

But the worst problem is that there is almost no motivation for anything that happens. People say, frequently, "I love YOU now", or "I don't love you any more. I'm leaving", or "I've been having an affair" and there is almost nothing prior on screen to indicate why. Apparently these schizo people just wake up one morning and decide to make major changes in their lives for no apparent reason.

The only sympathetic, flesh-and-blood, character is played by Natalie Portman. There is not a camera angle or pink wig that can make her look anything less than stunning. There is one scene, not sexual, where she is in bed with a lover she has just been reunited with, bouncing around like a puppy for joy. In this short scene she goes way beyond the words, to communicate utter contentment, hope for the future, vulnerability. Her acting was terrific and made the film worthwhile.

title: Why don't they make good movies anymore?
review:
Let me preface this by saying I'm a big fan of Julia Roberts and Natalie Portman as well as Jude Law. But this is one of those movies that movie snobs like to pretend is good just so they can look intelligent when it really just proves they don't have a mind of their own.

I find it hard to believe that the 3 above actors read the script and said "Oh yeah, I want to be in that movie!" If you are even thinking of having any children watch this with you or heaven forbid by themselves, please rethink that. It would be a very bad idea. But the sexual language isn't all I object to. It's just the pitiful humans that are represented by these actors. If this is supposed to be a portrayal of a "normal" relationship then I feel sorry for all those "normal" people out there. If you are looking for a feel-good movie, this is definitely not it.

With that said, I do see so much talent in Natalie Portman and I see her winning many Oscars in the future. She is really a terrific actress. Just be warned about the movie itself. I don't recommend it at all.

title: A boring movie not worth the time
review:
I just saw this movie last night, after hearing a lot about it, and I didn't really like it. It failed both as entertainment, and as art. It's not a love/hate response like some reviewers seem to be implying, it was just boring. Normally, for a movie this boring, I wouldn't waste my time writing a review, but I figured since so many people are raving about it, and that influenced my decision to see it, I'd warn others before they watched it.

I wasn't put off by the vulgar language, or the frankness about sex. I just didn't find the movie engaging. I already knew from a review I heard on the radio that none of the characters were going to be likable, so I was prepared for that and it didn't put me off. But if the purpose of art is supposed to be to evoke an emotional response, this movie failed. It's about four dislikable people, doing what you'd expect them to do. There's no sympathy towards the characters when they get screwed, because you don't like them to begin with, and no anger about what they're doing to the other characters, because the other characters are just as bad. So, it just ends up being a rather bland movie from the point of view of emotional response from the audience.

So, I wouldn't ever buy this movie, or take the time to watch it again, but that being said, not everything about this movie was awful. I think the actors and actresses did well acting their parts, there were a few humorous moments where me and my wife laughed, and (to completely lose all credibility of this review) Natalie Portman was easy on the eyes. But after watching this movie, I really just didn't like it. However, it seems that many people do, so if you like relationship movies about characters you don't like, where everybody gets what they deserve, and nobody ends up happy, go ahead and watch this movie.

title: Did not live up to the Hype
review: I have to say I was looking forward to seeing this movie. I rented it this week and I finally sat down and watched it. There was a big hype about it where I was and it was a movie everyone was talking about it. But when I sat back and watched it I found that I had a hard time keeping up and following time lines. They would flash back and then flash forward. The acting was great. Julia Roberts was as good as ever. But the acting does not make up for the hard to follow script. This movie is very close to the truth on what goes on in a love square. People bounce back and forth then back and then leave or stay where they are unhappy. In that respect it was very real. I found it to be a little too graphic for my taste in the scenes in the club. I have to say the hype for the movie made it seem like it would be another hall of fame movie while I found it not to be to those standards. It is worth seeing but at your own risk.

title: As much felt as seen... very good!
review:
** HERE BE SPOILERS **

Recap: Alice (Portman), a stripper and waitress and Dan, a failed writer, (Law) meet at a crossing, where Alice get hit by a cab. With just minor injuries Dan takes her to the hospital and so their relationship starts. Later Dan meets Anna (Roberts), while she is taking his photo for his book (based on Alice) and falls for her, while still living with Alice. Anna is interested but does not fall for Dan, but for Larry, a dermatologist. But at an art exhibition of Anna's photos, including one beautiful of Alice, Dan and Anna meet again and things start to happen...

Comments: A film about love, betrayal, illusions and disillusions, of hurt and pain and life in general. This movie is beautifully shot and narrated, using pictures and events as much as words. There are some jumps in the timeline, but not at all confusing. The performance of the actors, which is great all over, in addition to the work of writer and director, makes this a movie just as much felt as seen. There are laughs (much thanks to a witty dialog) and there are sorrows. I guess most can relate to some scene or another (I sure could) and therefore we can feel, actually feel what the characters do. Actually a better trick than any special effect could do. This was worth every penny spent, and well worth the time. Recommended.

9/10

title: Pedestrian
review:
I don't have a lot to say about this movie, as it left me largely un-moved by the shenanigans of the characters. First no-one is together, then "Alice" and Dan get together as do Anna and Larry. There is a small amount of humour in how Larry and Anna meet - Dan is on the interweb in some chatroom, pretending to be Anna and gets into some pretty puerile sex talk with Larry. It really was rubbish. They agree to meet at the Aquarium, which it just so happens is where Anna is sitting. So, some interesting play with identity - Larry is full of references from his sex talk and Anna, of course, has no idea what he's talking about.

But then Dan "loves" Anna, so of course they have to get together, and damn the consequences. Not that I cared for either Larry, who was pretty much a jerk, or Anna. In only a couple of scenes could I summon up any affection for Dan - right near the end, he seemed like a decent enough fellow for a bit, but then he turned out to not be. At least he could recognize that his need to know, his need to have the truth, made him an idiot - I could admire him for that, but then he couldn't handle the truth (if, in fact, it was given to him - I rather suspect he was not).

Which brings me to the only character I could feel anything for. "Alice" turns up in London (ex USA) as a waif on an expedition. She meets Dan thanks to a small car accident - it was kind of cute, the way he went with her to the hospital, stayed with her, then when it came time to part, he did so formally, only to wheel around and come back for her. She loves him, perhaps needly. Once Dan goes after Anna, "Alice" returns to her former work as a stripper. The best scene, not because of her near nudity but because of the way she played it, was in the strip bar - Larry has come in for a bit of fun, recognizes her and wants to break through her professional mask, get her to tell him something "real". She insists her name is Jane, but never drops the mask: since Larry knows her as Alice, it never occurs to him that that might have been the mask and that this is the truth. So, she keeps saying she is Jane, he keeps throwing money at her and shows he really isn't a pleasant fellow at all.

title: initially bewildered but grew to love
review:
Midway thru the movie, my wife asked me what I thought of the movie and for the first time ever I said "I don't know yet, ask me when its over". When it was over, I still wasn't sure. The next morning I decided I loved the move, however she didn't like it at all. Even the soundtrack is compelling and gets stuck in my head.

I had to watch it a second time to appreciate it even further, however it is a very artistic film and is not for the average action/drama moviegoer.

postmetamorphasis analyzed this movie perfectly, I am not as poignant as postM so I'll leave the thesis to him.

title: Play Vs. Movie
review: This movie is without a doubt one of the most amazing films I've seen for quite a while, but as a huge fan of Marber, I was a little upset when comparing the two. Both are excellent, but if we're being honest, don't see both. Choose one or the other. The play is more depressing, but also much more brutally honest whereas, in the process of taking the play to the big screen, several things had to be changed to make it more Hollywood, a.k.a. less depressing. Another thing that kinda got to me was the Britishness of it all. It was supposed to be British, it was good British, but when you get two American actresses to play the lead roles, see if you can get rid of the British slang, they just sound kinda dumb saying it.

title: A Magnificent guilty peek into relationships
review:
The entire movie I felt like I was over hearing a conversation I wasn't supposed to hear. Almost like a couple arguing at a bus stop or in a mall. You get all the raw emotion and pain. It feels like it's being spat at you and thrown onto you like heavy weights. You can not look away but it's making you feel used and hurt and sad and angry all at the same time.

This was one of the best films I have ever seen executed, from start to finish. It was gorgeous and ugly at the exact same time. The actors really made you feel what they were saying. Relationship movies now a days tend to be shallow and squeaky clean. This definitely wasn't one of those movies. I recommend this whole heartedly to anyone who has an open mind and loves to feel movies not just watch them. This film mirrors life...and love and heart ache. Go see it...it's well worth it. Maybe just maybe it will restore your faith as it did mine in Hollywood movies.

title: Dreams and delusions
review:
Is love a disease? a delusion? A timeless question as important today as ever. We accept this premise, but what other diseases can exist in our minds? Is there a spectrum of possibilities beyond the debilitating sort that are legally certifiable?

Without telling us any answers, without subtext leading us to believe in a solution, this film analyzes fear and doubt in a particularly common variety. Does love exist? Must it be pure? True?

The film is excellent in every infinitesimal aspect that I'm aware of. Script, Cast, Performance, Photography, Sound, Direction. It's all I can do to write my praises.

The trip was almost more than I could bear. Which is everything this should be.

title: Hats Off It hit me
review: Which character was the movie? Give license - it is from stage. A controller A deceiver A less mature and selfish deceiver and I'm everything I'm nothing I'm crying out my name. Alone no one pure enough to call her out to know her story to read her book to know her name. Tragic and so identifiable this human condition. A great work! Was it me or was this about Alice and Jane. He wrote her life published her book but never met her. She wanted so much to be found to know how far she was lost. And sadly she was left not loved but left lost and unloved. To take up another identity and once more removed from reality.

title: Good, almost for everyone
review: The best movie I saw this year. I think, everyone will find himself in the movie's characters. Great actors' play, great screenplay, wonderful music. Need more? I don't think You would find it. Real story for real people. My friend said that this movie was made from many others, excepting their mistakes... I don't think so. This movie broke my heart and my soul. It just make me to review my life and relationships again. As Larry (CLive Owen) said: "I like only my ex-girlfriends". And characters' pain and feelings go from the screen to us, it make us understand our life's mistakes. I don't want to be boring for You. My opinion: YOU MUST SEE IT!

title: Just a thanks
review:
This isn't really a review...

I just want to say that I'm thankful that Julia Roberts and Natalie Portman took these roles. They were risky and they did great, as all can see by the other reviews. Julia Roberts, especially, made a break from her usual fluff roles and finally sunk her teeth into something juicy and adult. I'm sure a lot of the moms-who-watch-Oprah are going to be shocked at her in this role, but personally I applaud her decision and I hope to see her in more films like this.

And I love that Natalie Portman is all grown up. I've been following her career since she started and I always knew she was going to be the next Merly Streep.

title: love, if you mess with it, it will mess with you
review:
a wonderful look at passion. It takes off where Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind left, a promising beginning of confirmed matches and ends right where it starts, a huge pack of memories to last a lifetime of regretfulness.

The acting is amazing and an hour and fifty minutes is barely enough for the grand message the movie tries to carry.

I just wish they substituted the word "love" in the whole movie with something else so the message of it's semi-existent state of being would be better understood. I also wish they substituted physical beauty of the personalities, but I guess that would bring in far more complexity then a play can handle.

I just finished watching Closer and all I can say is what was the purpose of this movie? Perhaps it's because I couldn't relate to the characters. To me, sex does not equal love. It's almost a distraction at times. None of the characters were ever in love with each other, they all had meaningless purely physical relationships. Perhaps that was the point of the movie, to show how far society has sunk into carnal pleasures over actual affection and commitment to a person you care about. IF that's the case, it's been done before countless times. Also, I felt that Natalie Portman, as nice as she is to look at, turned in her usual crap performance. The others in the film were par; all this talk of Oscar consideration is way out of the question. I also felt that the story was a tad predictable after the first switch occurred; it was pretty obvious that no one was going to end up happy no matter what happened. Still, I forced myself to watch the whole thing to confirm my prediction.

If you like petty sex dramas, and aren't mature enough to realize that sex does not equal love, then watch this movie, you might learn something.

title: Vulgar dialogue doesn't make a good film
review:
Having only seen a TV ad for this movie, and based on the poster, I was expecting a romantic comedy or love story - some sort of "chick flick" - wrong. Being a fan of Natalie Portman, it expected that her presence would make the film worthwhile, and I like Julie Roberts too. After enduring the movie I had to wonder why Julie, and more so Natalie, would chose to be a part of something this (verbally) graphic and vulgar. I can only assume she wanted to "demonstrate her versatility" or some such thing. It's a safe bet George Lucas would not be pleased to see Queen Amidala spreading her legs wide - I joked at the time that "now we know what drives Anakin Skywalker to become Darth Vader".

All four actors do their job well enough, and the cinematography likewise gets a passing grade, although it's - appropriately enough - dark. Aside from the somewhat jarring presence of porn dialogue in a love story, this film's main failing is that you don't care that these characters are destroying their own relationships. Natalie's character is the most sympathetic, but all four suffer from their own bad choices. One of them even says "you made the choice" to cheat - it doesn't "just happen" as is so often the excuse.

There are probably real people whom are as weak - even pathetic - as the four in "Closer", but I don't want to watch them, and worse pay to do so.

title: Four characters that don't have a clue.
review:
Great actors and actresses, but they can't save a pitiful screenplay. All four of the leads can act well, but the people they are portraying don't have the first idea what love truly is.
